questions.text: A 42-year-old HIV-positive male presents with 2 weeks of cough, fever, night sweats, weight loss and diarrhoea. He is not on ART and has a CD4 count of <10/ μL. Which of the following infections is most likely?
questions.solution:
Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) infection is most likely. 

Mycobacterium avium complex, or Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare complex, is a group of slow-growing, nonchromogenic non-tuberculous mycobacteria. The infections occur in both immunocompetent and immunosuppressed patients. It is the most frequent organism affecting HIV and immunosuppressed patients, although about 40% of pulmonary infections occur in immunocompetent patients. Cervical lymphadenitis is the most common presentation in young children of age <5 years. Other manifestations include skin, and soft tissue infections, musculoskeletal infections, and disseminated disease

Treatment with either clarithromycin or azithromycin plus ethambutol is a preferred initial therapy along with starting anti-retroviral therapy.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man is rushed to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, abdominal distension, and obstipation. His erect X-ray abdomen is as shown. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 64-year-old man with severe abdominal pain, abdominal distension, and obstipation along with the radiograph showing the coffee bean sign is likely to be sigmoid volvulus.

Sigmoid volvulus is a condition that occurs when the sigmoid colon twists on the sigmoid mesocolon.

A sigmoid volvulus can be differentiated from a cecal volvulus by swirl sign, location of the obstructed loop, and anatomical appendages. The swirl with sigmoid volvulus is located on the right quadrant while the swirl with cecal volvulus is located at the pelvic brim. 

Other options:

Option B: Colonic diverticulosis refers to the condition where multiple outpouchings occur along the gastrointestinal tract without any inflammation. The barium enema given below shows multiple outpouchings in the ascending, transverse, and descending colon resembling a saw-tooth. 

Option C: Cecal volvulus is more common in females in the 4th to 5th decade. It is characterized by ischemia. 

Option D: Paralytic ileus occurs secondary to neuromuscular failure. This leads to the failure of transmission of peristaltic waves. It mainly occurs following laparotomy. The image given below is an X-ray of a patient with a paralytic ileus.

Differences between the small bowel and large bowel obstruction:

Features Small bowel Large bowel
Valvulae conniventes Present in jejunum Absent
No of Loops Many Few
Distribution of loops Central Peripheral
Haustra Absent Present
Diameter 3-5 cm >5 cm
Solid feces Absent Present

questions.text: Which of the following parameter is used in the calculation of the pearl index?
questions.solution:
The parameter used in the calculation of the pearl index is total accidental pregnancies.

Pearl Index:

  • The pearl index is defined as the number of failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

It can be calculated as follows.

  • The total accidental pregnancies must include all pregnancies irrespective of the outcome(live births, still-births or abortions).
  • The total months of exposure is obtained by deducting 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

questions.text: All of the following are AIDS defining illnesses except:
questions.solution:
Oral candidiasis(thrush) is not an AIDS-defining illness. Candidiasis of the esophagus, bronchi, trachea, or lungs is an AIDS-defining illness.

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasms found in patients with HIV infection

Infections

  • Protozoal and Helminthic Infections
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal Infections
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial Infections
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral Infections
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix 

 

One-liners about HIV

  • Sexual contact is the least efficacious yet most common mode of spread of HIV infection
  • ELISA is used for the detection of antibodies against viral proteins. This is the most sensitive and the best screening test for the diagnosis of AIDS.
  • Western blot is the most specific or the confirmatory test for HIV.
  • Candidiasis is the most common fungal infection in patients with AIDS.
  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV) chorioretinitis exclusively in patients with CD4+ T cell counts less than 50 per microliter.
  • Toxoplasma gondii causes encephalitis and is responsible for 50% of all mass lesions in the central nervous system.
  • John Cunningham virus (JC virus) is a human papovavirus that causes progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy.
  • Persistent diarrhea in AIDS is caused by Cryptosporidium, Isospora belli, or microsporidia.
  • AIDS-dementia complex is the most common neurological manifestation of HIV infection.
  • Inflammatory myopathy is the commonest skeletal muscle disorder in HIV.

questions.text: In a patient with critical limb ischemia, what is the ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI) likely to be?
questions.solution:
In a patient with critical limb ischemia, the ABPI is < 0.3.

Related Pearl: Ankle–brachial Pressure Index (ABPI)

The ankle-brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the arm.

The numerator is the highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery and the denominator is the highest brachial systolic pressure.

ABPI Reading Interpretation
>0.91 < 1.3 Normal
<0.9 Diagnostic of occlusive arterial disease in patients with symptoms of claudication or other signs of ischemia
0.5 to 0.9 Arterial obstruction often associated with claudication
<0.3 Critical limb ischemia (multilevel obstruction i.e any combination of iliac, femoral or tibial vessel disease and may be associated with non-healing ulcerations, ischemic rest pain, or pedal gangrene.
>1.4 Signifies poor compressibility of the arteries. Mostly due to calcification because of increased age, diabetes etc.

Note: A fall in the resting ABPI of more than 20% after exercise is indicative of arterial disease.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with fibroid uterus develops acute pain in abdomen with low grade fever and leukocytosis at 28 weeks. The most likely diagnosis is ______
questions.solution:
In the given scenario history of acute pain abdomen with fever and mild leukocytosis in a 28-week pregnant woman is suggestive of red degeneration of fibroid.

Red degeneration is the most common complication of fibroids in pregnancy. It is due to the breakdown of fibroid resulting in ischemia and pain. Key clinical features of this condition are, low-grade fever, tender uterus on palpation, elevated leukocytes and elevated esr.

The diagnosis is confirmed with an ultrasound. It is usually self-limiting and can be managed with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.

Other options:

Option B: Torsion of subserous pedunculated fibroid presents with severe pain abdomen but fever and leucocytosis are absent.

Option C: Infection is common in submucous and myomatous polyps if they project into the cervical canal or the vagina. An infected polyp can cause blood-stained purulent discharge. Infection is more likely in the postpartum and postabortal states.

Option D: Preterm labour is defined as regular uterine contractions with or without pain (at least one every 10 minutes), dilatation (> 2 cm) and effacement (80%) of the cervix, length of the cervix (measured by TVS) < 2.5 cm and funnelling of the internal os and pelvic pressure, backache and/or vaginal discharge or bleeding.

questions.text: Two brothers were arguing over ancestral property when the elder of the two suddenly complained of chest pain. He was brought to the hospital. His family members reported that he was previously healthy and that there were no similar diseases in the family members. Echocardiography was done; the image below shows the findings. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of sudden chest pain in a previously healthy man under a stressful situation is suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is also called broken heart syndrome, apical ballooning syndrome, or stress-induced cardiomyopathy. It is characterized by a transient myocardial stunning from microcirculation spams due to a catecholamine surge during stress. It is usually seen in middle-aged women. The patients may present with pulmonary edema, hypotension, and chest pain.

Echocardiography reveals apical dilatation with basal hypercontraction of the heart, resembling a takotsubo (pot for catching octopus). The ECG changes can mimic those of myocardial infarction. Therefore, coronary angiography may be needed to rule out coronary occlusion. 

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is a self-limiting disorder, resolving within days to weeks. The prognosis is generally good.

questions.text: Which of the following is an epiphyseal lesion?
questions.solution:
Chondroblastoma is an epiphyseal lesion.

Following are the epiphyseal lesions:

  • Chondroblastoma
  • Giant cell tumor in adults
  • Clear chondrosarcoma
  • Articular osteochondroma (Trevor's disease)

 

Related Pearl: Most common sites of primary bone tumors

EPIPHYSEAL :

  • Chondroblastoma 
  • Giant cell tumor in adults
  • Articular osteochondroma (trevor’s disease)
  • Clear cell chondrosarcoma 

DIAPHYSEAL:

  • Round cell lesions-Ewing’s sarcoma 
  • Lymphoma
  • Multiple myeloma
  • Adamantinoma
  • Osteoid osteoma
  • Fibrous dysplasia
  • Histiocytosis
  • Osteoblastoma

METAPHYSEAL:

  • Chondrosarcoma (Note:Clear cell chondrosarcoma is epiphyseal)
  • Enchondroma
  • Osteochondroma
  • Bone cyst
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Giant cell tumor in children

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement about obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD)?

choices.text: Atypical antipsychotics is the first line treatment
Prevalence is 7 -10 percent in general population

questions.solution:
Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is commonly associated with depression. The lifetime prevalence of major depressive disorder in patients with OCD is 67%. Other common psychiatric comorbidities in patients with OCD are social phobia, alcohol use disorders, panic, and personality disorders.

Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) comprises symptoms that include intrusive thoughts, preoccupations, and compulsions. These recurrent obses­sions or compulsions cause severe distress to the patient. The patient might have an obsession, a compulsion, or both. The prevalence of OCD among the general population is 2-3 %

An obsession is a thought, feeling, or sensation that is repetitive and intrusive. A compulsion is a conscious, recurrent behaviour, eg: counting, or checking, and is done to reduce the anxiety associated with the obsession. However, this act may not reduce the anxiety and might increase the anxiety even more. 

Symptom patterns:

  • Contamination - This is the most common symptom pattern of OCD.  The patient feels that the objects are contaminated. They repeatedly wash their hands or avoid touching objects which are thought to be contaminated. In extreme cases, patients may rub the skin off their hands due to excessive hand washing or may refuse to leave the house for fear of germs.
  • Pathological doubt - This is the second most common symptom pattern. The patient presents with an obsession with doubt and a compulsion to check. This obsession arises due to possible danger or violence (e.g., forgetting to turn off the stove or not locking a door) which is followed by multiple trips to check. For example, repeated checking if the stove is turned off, if the door is locked, etc.
  • Intrusive thoughts -This is the third most common symptom pattern. These patients have intrusive obsessional thoughts without compulsion. These thoughts could be sexual or an aggressive act that the patient doesn't agree with. The patients might report themselves to the police or confess to a spiritual leader.
  • Symmetry - This is the fourth most common pattern which can lead to a compulsion of slowness. Patients can take hours to eat a meal or shave their faces.

Diagnosis:

  1. Presence of obsessions, compulsions or both
  2. Symptoms are time-consuming
  3. Symptoms not related to substance abuse
  4. Not better explained by other mental disorders

Treatment of OCD includes:

  • Pharmacotherapy: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRI) or clomipramine
  • Behavioural therapy: Approaches include:
    • Exposure and response prevention
    • Desensitization
    • Thought stopping
    • Flooding
    • Implosion therapy
    • Aversive conditioning

A combination of behavioural and pharmacotherapy is most effective.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the condition given below?

choices.text: Patient must be started on anti-gas gangrene serum therapy
It is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection

questions.solution:
The given image is suggestive of Fournier's gangrene. It is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection.

It is a polymicrobial infection and a type of necrotizing fasciitis of the perineum, external genitalia, and perianal region. Risk factors include immunocompromised states such as HIV, alcoholism, diabetes, etc. The infection may be precipitated by minor procedures in the perineal area, such as a bruise, scratch, urethral dilatation, injection of haemorrhoids, or opening of a periurethral abscess. The infection spreads along the dartos, Scarpa's, and Colle's fascia.

The sequence of events that lead to the development of gangrene are as follows: A mixed infection of the aerobic and anaerobic bacteria  → fulminating inflammation of subcutaneous tissue → obliterative arteritis of the arterioles that supply the scrotal skin → gangrene.

Clinical features are scrotal pain, fever, prostration, and pallor. Cellulitis spreads rapidly and may be associated with eschars, necrosis, flaking skin, and crepitus. The testis is usually not affected, and hence, bilateral orchidectomy is not performed. It is also called "shameful exposure of the testis". 

Diagnosis is majorly clinical and very rarely made by laboratory or imaging findings. 

Management involves the administration of IV fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and urgent surgical debridement. When the infection has been controlled, vacuum-assisted dressing may be helpful. Anti-gas gangrene serum therapy has no role in Fournier's gangrene.

questions.text: A patient was evaluated for dysphagia, and barium swallow shows the following image. The probable diagnosis is ________
questions.solution:
The image shows a corkscrew esophagus, which is seen in diffuse esophageal spasm.

Diffuse Esophageal Spasm - It is a hypermotility disorder of the esophagus seen more commonly in women.  Patients usually present with dysphagia and chest pain which is caused by spontaneous, abnormal contractions seen more in the distal two-thirds of the oesophageal body. However, in between the contractions, peristalsis remains normal. Pathologically, there is marked hypertrophy of the circular muscles.

A barium swallow shows a corkscrew esophagus. However, manometry is the gold standard test for diagnosis. Simultaneous, multi-peaked contractions of high amplitude (>120 mmHg) or long duration (>2.5 seconds) are suggestive of DES (as given in the question).

Treatment: Calcium-channel antagonists, vasodilators, and endoscopic dilatation have only transient effects. Surgical treatment includes extended/long oesophageal myotomy, up to the aortic arch, if required. The surgical treatment of DES is more successful in improving dysphagia than chest pain.

questions.text: A 3-day old neonate of a diabetic mother presents with progressively deepening cyanosis and tachypnea since birth. The chest  X-ray of the neonate is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A clinical scenario of an infant born to a diabetic mother, presenting with progressive cyanosis and tachypnea with an X-ray showing the egg-on-side appearance is suggestive of transposition of great arteries. 

TGA is the most specific heart disease in infants of diabetic mothers and is more common in males.

The deoxygenated blood returning from the body goes inappropriately out the aorta and back to the body again, while oxygenated pulmonary venous blood is returned directly to the lungs.

Survival in the immediate neonatal period is due to the mixture of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood provided by the foramen ovale and the ductus arteriosus. 50% of patients also have a ventricular septal defect (VSD).

Chest X-rays show mild cardiomegaly, a narrow mediastinum (the classic egg-shaped heart or egg-on-string appearance), with normal to increased pulmonary blood flow.

Egg-on-side or globular-shaped heart is due to an abnormal convexity of the right atrial border and left atrial enlargement, and therefore appears like an egg.

 

An ECHO confirms the transposed ventricular-arterial connection and is diagnostic. A color doppler examination is used to visualize the size of the interatrial communication and the ductus arteriosus. It also assesses the degree of mixing, and presence of any associated ventricular outflow tract obstruction, or a septal defect. 

Other options:

Option A: Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVC) occurs due to the anomalous connection of pulmonary veins instead of joining to the left atrium resulting in pulmonary venous blood reaching the right atrium. 

In supracardiac (TAPVC)  the configuration of the heart and the superior mediastinal borders resemble a snowman. It is also referred to as the figure of 8 sign as shown below.

 

Option B: Ebstein anomaly is a rare cyanotic congenital heart disease with diminished pulmonary blood flow due to abnormality of the tricuspid valve. This occurs as a fetal anomaly due to the action of antenatal intake of lithium. 

In the Ebstein anomaly, there is severe right-sided cardiomegaly due to an elongated and enlarged right atrium which leads to an elevated apex giving a box-shaped heart as shown below.

Option C: Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)  is the most common cyanotic heart disease encountered beyond the age of 1 year. It is characterized by tetrad of:

  • Severe right ventricle outflow obstruction
  • Large VSD
  • Aorta overriding VSD
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy

In the TOF, the hypertrophied right ventricle causes the rounded apical shadow to be uptilted so that it is situated higher above the diaphragm than normal. This on X-rays appears as a boot-shaped heart or Coeur en sabot as shown below.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with an increased nighttime itching and lesions that are more during the winter months?
questions.solution:
Skin lesions that increase during the winter months and that cause more itching during the nighttime are seen with scabies.

Scabies is an ectoparasitic skin infection that is transmitted through the means of close personal contact/fomites. It is caused by the mite Sarcoptes scabiei var hominis or human itch mite. It leads to severe pruritis, excoriating papules, and burrows. The pruritis typically shows nocturnal exacerbations. In adults, the face is often spared. Typical sites include the finger webs, the flexor surfaces of the wrists, elbows, axillae, buttocks, and genitalia. The typical lesions of scabies are burrows.

The following techniques can be used to diagnose scabies:

  • Skin scraping and microscopy - The material is scraped off with a blunt scalpel and is placed in mineral oil on a microscope slide. The presence of mites, eggs, fragments of eggshells, or scybala (hardened masses of faeces) confirms the diagnosis.
  • Dermoscopy - Useful for detecting burrows and visualizing their contents.
    • 10x magnification - mini triangle sign, maturing eggs that show minute heads of maturing mites within the egg.
    • 40x magnification - The mite in its burrow resembles a ‘jet‐with‐contrail’.
  • Adhesive-tape test - After firmly applying the adhesive side of the tape onto an appropriate skin lesion of patient, the tape is pulled off and transferred directly onto a slide for microscopy to visualize the mites.
  • Skin biopsy.

Treatment:

  • A single overnight application of 5% permethrin cream from neck to toe in adults and from head to toe in children is the drug of choice for the treatment of scabies in all ages including infants (at least 2 months old) and pregnant women.
  • Topical sulfur applications can be safely used in infants less than 2 months of age, as well as in breastfeeding and pregnant mothers.
  • Topical 1% Lindane cream is contraindicated in children, pregnant ladies, and seizure disorders as it is known to cause neurotoxicity.
  • All family members, even if asymptomatic, need to be treated simultaneously for this condition to prevent reinfection.
  • Clothing needs to be disinfected simultaneously.
  • Ivermectin and benzyl benzoate are contraindicated in pregnancy.

The image below shows a photo of a scabies burrow. The large scaly patch at the left is due to scratching. At the upper right, the scabies mite can be seen at the end of the burrow.

The Sarcoptes scabies mite is shown in the image below.

Other options:

Option A: Patients with tinea infection present with circular plaques with a sharp margin and raised edges that are itchy. 

The image below shows a lesion in tinea corporis.

Option C: Psoriasis presents with well-demarcated, erythematous plaques with silvery scale, commonly affecting extensor surfaces such as the elbows and knees. It is often associated with nail changes and may involve systemic manifestations such as psoriatic arthritis. Given below is an image of plaque psoriasis.

Option D: Photodermatosis refers to a group of skin conditions caused or exacerbated by exposure to sunlight or UV radiation. It can result in rashes, itching, or other skin reactions, often requiring sun protection or medical treatment.

Related Pearl: Difference between classic and neonatal scabies

  Classic scabies Neonatal scabies
Site of involvement Interdigital webs, trunk, genitals, flexors, sparing of palms and soles, and skin above neck Face, scalp, palm, and soles
Morphology of Lesion Papules, pustules, excoriation, eczematization, burrow Vesicles, pustules, bullae, erosions, and ulcerations
Burrows Present Usually absent

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication to OCP use?
questions.solution:
Thromboembolism is an absolute contraindication to OCP use.

Contraindications of OCPs:

  • Absolute contraindications -
    • Breast and genital cancers
    • Liver disease
    • History of thromboembolism- DVT, stroke
    • Congenital hyperlipidemia
    • Undiagnosed AUB.
  • Relative contraindications - 
     
    • Pregnancy
    • Uncontrolled hypertension
    • Chronic renal disease
    • If she is a smoker aged >35 years
    • Migraine with aura
    • First 6 months of nursing
    • Diabetes with vascular involvement
    • Gallbladder disease
    • History of infrequent bleeding or amenorrhea

questions.text: As per the WHO labour care guidelines, documentation of labour progression begins at _____.
questions.solution:
As per the WHO Labour Care Guidelines, documentation on the LCG should begin at 5 cm of dilation.

WHO modified partograph WHO Labour Care Guide
Documentation of labour progression begins at 4 cm of cervical dilatation Documentation of labour progression begins at 5 cm of cervical dilatation
Fixed 1 cm/hour ‘alert’ and ‘action’ lines Time-based cut-offs for each centimetre of cervical dilatation to guide the obstetrician to take action. For example, at 5 cm of cervical dilatation, if there is no progress >6 hours, action needs to be taken
Monitoring of labour is restricted to the first stage only Monitoring of second stage of labour is included
No section on supportive care interventions Addition of a section on supportive care of the mother
Documentation of strength, duration, and frequency of uterine contractions Documentation of only the duration and frequency of uterine contractions

The image below shows modified WHO partograph.

The image below shows WHO labour care guide.

questions.text: A patient presents with multiple episodes of vomiting. Which of the following laboratory results would be seen in his arterial blood gas analysis?
questions.solution:
Hydrochloric acid (HCl) is lost due to vomiting. Loss of HCl results in HCO3− generation causing metabolic alkalosis. Among the given options, high pH (7.55) and high HCO3- (30 mEq/L) are suggestive of metabolic alkalosis. A high pCO2 (48 mmHg) represents respiratory acidosis as a result of compensatory hypoventilation.

Hypochloremia occurs because of loss of HCl during vomiting and is maintained due to loss of Cl- in the kidney which accompanies increased HCO3-reabsorption

Multiple episodes of vomiting result in loss of acids from the body and thus increases the pH.

questions.text: A patient who was admitted after a road traffic accident (RTA) is put on mechanical ventilation. He opens his eyes on verbal commands and both pupils are well reactive. He moves all 4 limbs spontaneously. What is his GCS score
questions.solution:
The GCS score in this patient can be documented as Eyes-3, Verbal-NT, Motor-6, and Pupil-0.

  • Eye-opening to verbal command - 3 
  • In endotracheal intubation, the verbal response cannot be tested. It is documented as NT.
  • Movement of all 4 limbs spontaneously - 6
  • Both the pupils are reactive- 0

The total GCS score is not recorded since one of the components is non-testable (NT).

The GCS-P is calculated by subtracting the Pupil Reactivity Score (PRS) from the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) total score:

GCS-P = GCS - PRS

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild brain injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate brain injury
  • scores ≤8 represent severe brain injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal/flexion 4
Abnormal flexion/Decorticate posturing  3
Extension/Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • The motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils Unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

questions.text: A 10-month-old infant was brought with complaints of jerking movements of limbs towards the body. During the attack, the baby typically attains complete heaving of the head forward towards the knees, and then immediately relaxes into the upright position. On examination, there is a regression in developmental milestones. What would be the EEG finding in this case?

choices.text: 1.5-2.5 Hz spike and polyspike bursts in sleep

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of West syndrome. The EEG in this child would show hypsarrhythmia.

West syndrome is severe generalized epilepsy that begins between the ages of 2 and 12 months. It is characterized by a triad of: 

  1. Infantile epileptic spasms
  2. Developmental regression
  3. Hypsarrhythmia on electroencephalogram (EEG)

Hypsarrhythmia refers to a high voltage, slow, chaotic background with multifocal spikes as shown below.

West syndrome has been known by many names like infantile spasms, salaam attacks, salaam convulsions infantile spastic epilepsy, and jackknife convulsion syndrome. During an attack babies typically attain complete heaving of the head forward towards their knees, and then immediately relax into the upright position.

The image given below illustrates infantile spasms in a child.

Diagnosis is confirmed by EEG which typically shows hypsarrythmia.

The treatment of choice in West syndrome is either adreno-corticotropic hormone (ACTH) or corticosteroids. An antiseizure medication, mainly vigabatrin can be used when associated with tuberous sclerosis.

Note: The table given below shows t3he EEG features seen in various seizure disorders.

Disease Typical EEG feature
Lennox-Gastaut syndrome 1.5-2.5 Hz spike and polyspike bursts in sleep
Absence seizures 3 Hz spike and slow-wave (spike and dome pattern)
Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy 4-5 Hz spike
West syndrome Hypsarrhythmia (high-voltage waves with chaotic background)

questions.text: A 36-year-old female patient presents with symptoms of hyperparathyroidism, pituitary adenoma, and gastrinoma with cutaneous angiofibromas. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of MEN 1 syndrome.

Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) syndromes are characterized by tumors of two or more endocrine glands. There are four major types of MEN (MEN 1–4), and they either show an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance or occur sporadically. 

MEN 1, also known as Wermer’s syndrome, is characterized by the triad of parathyroid, pancreatic islet cell, and anterior pituitary tumors. Adrenal cortical tumors, carcinoid tumors, facial angiofibromas, collagenomas, thyroid tumors, and lipomas may also occur. MEN 1-associated tumors are usually multiple, larger, and more aggressive, resulting in resistance to treatment and poor patient outcomes.

  1. Parathyroid tumors- primary hyperparathyroidism is the most common feature of MEN 1. Hypercalcemia with or without symptoms (polyuria, polydipsia, constipation, dyspepsia), nephrolithiasis, and osteitis fibrosa cystica may also occur. All four parathyroid glands are usually affected with multiple adenomas or hyperplasia. 
  2. Pancreatic islet cell tumors- these are neuroendocrine tumors, including:
    • Gastrinoma (gastrin-secreting tumors)- associated with increased gastric acid secretion and multiple peptic ulcers (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome). Patients may present with diarrhea and steatorrhea. Gastrinomas are the major cause of mortality and morbidity. 
    • Insulinoma (insulin-secreting tumors)- patients present with hypoglycemic symptoms (weakness, headaches, sweating, seizures, weight gain) that develop after fasting or exertion and improve after glucose intake. Along with increased plasma insulin levels and hypoglycemia, increased C peptide and proinsulin levels help in diagnosing the condition.
    • Glucagonoma (glucagon-secreting tumors)- may be associated with necrolytic migratory erythema, weight loss, anemia, and stomatitis. 
    • VIPomas (Vasoactive intestinal peptide [VIP]-secreting tumors): The VIPoma syndrome, also known as Verner-Morrison syndrome, is characterized by watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria. These are mostly located in the tail of the pancreas.
    • PPomas (Pancreatic polypeptide-secreting tumors) and nonfunctioning pancreatic tumors- are associated with a worse prognosis as they often go undiagnosed due to the absence of both clinical features and biochemical abnormalities.
  3. Pituitary tumors- manifestations depend on the hormone secreted (symptoms of hyperprolactinemia, acromegaly, or Cushing’s disease) and tumor size (visual disturbances or hypopituitarism due to compression of the optic chiasm or normal pituitary tissue). 

Surgical excision of the nonmetastatic tumor after localization is the curative treatment. Appropriate medical therapy can be used for some tumors when surgery is contraindicated or unsuccessful (calcimemetics for parathyroid tumors, parietal cell H+-K+-ATPase inhibitors for gastrinomas). In case of metastasis, chemotherapy, hormonal therapy, radiation therapy, and artery embolization may be successful.

MEN 1 occurs due to a mutation in the MEN1 gene located on chromosome 11q13. Mutational genetic analysis is necessary to confirm the clinical diagnosis and identify family members who harbor the mutation and require screening for tumor detection and early treatment.

Other options:

Options B and C: MEN 2, also called Sipple’s syndrome, is characterized by medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC), pheochromocytomas, and parathyroid tumors. This occurs due to mutations of the rearranged during transfection (RET) protooncogene. There are three clinical variants -

  1. MEN 2A (most common): MTC is associated with pheochromocytomas in 50% of patients and parathyroid tumors in 20% of patients. MEN 2A may also be associated with Hirschsprung’s disease and cutaneous lichen amyloidosis.
  2. MEN 2B (MEN 3): MTC is associated with pheochromocytoma, along with Marfanoid habitus; mucosal neuromas of the lips, tongue, and eyelids; medullated corneal fibers; and intestinal autonomic ganglion dysfunction leading to multiple diverticulae and megacolon. Parathyroid tumors are usually absent.
  3. MTC only (FMTC): MTC is the only manifestation.

Option D: MEN 4 is characterized by a combination of MEN 1–associated tumors and CDKN1B mutation-related tumors (gonadal, adrenal, renal, and thyroid tumors).

Related Pearl: MEN 1 Syndrome Features

Chromosome 11q13 / MEN1 gene

Also known as Wermer’s syndrome

Characteristic tumors seen in:

  • Parathyroid adenoma – 90 % - Most common overall
  • Entero pancreatic tumors - Most common functioning tumor is gastrinoma (most common site is duodenum)
  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma
  • Mnemonic – Par Pan Pit – in decreasing order of frequency

Associated tumors are:

  • Angiofibroma
  • Collagenomas
  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Lipoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors - gastric, thymic, lungs
  • Meningioma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Carcinoid tumors, usually of the foregut

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presented to the clinic with the lesions shown below. Which of the following conditions is/are associated with this the lesion?
questions.solution:
The lesions shown in the image are spider naevi and all of the conditions mentioned can be associated with it.

Spider naevi (nevus araneus) are vascular lesions characterized by the tortuous dilatation of arterioles just underneath the skin. On applying and releasing pressure over the lesion they typically fill from the center outward.

They are seen in:

  • Estrogen excess states such as pregnancy and OCP use.
  • Chronic liver disease - especially alcoholic liver disease, and
  • Thyrotoxicosis

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate way to assess adequate fluid correction in a patient with burns?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate way to assess adequate fluid correction in a burn patient is by measuring urine output. 

The urine output should be maintained between 0.5 to 1mL/kg body weight/hour.

Urine output is an indicator of kidney perfusion, which is an indicator of overall organ perfusion. Maintaining organ perfusion is the primary goal of IV fluid therapy in burn patients. If the urine output is low and the patient presents with signs of hypoperfusion (restlessness with tachycardia, cool peripheries, high hematocrit). A bolus of 10 mL/kg body weight should be administered. 

Other options: 

Option A: The parkland formula is a tool to estimate fluid requirement, and not assess the adequacy of fluid correction.

Option B: Mean arterial blood pressure is measured when the patient has a complex burn with cardiac dysfunction. 

Option D: Hematocrit values are measured when overhydration or dehydration is suspected in complex burns.

questions.text: Which of the following type of pelvis is most commonly associated with deep transverse arrest?
questions.solution:
The type of pelvis associated with deep transverse arrest is android pelvis as it has a prominent ischial spine.

The anatomical classification of the pelvis based on shape was given by Caldwell and Moloy.

The greatest transverse diameter of the pelvic inlet divides the pelvis into anterior and posterior segments. The shapes of these segments help classify the pelvis as follows:

  • Gynecoid
  • Anthropoid
  • Android
  • Platypelloid

 

  Gynecoid  Anthropoid  Android  Platypelloid 
Inlet Shape  Round 

Anteroposteriorly oval 

 Triangular/ Heart-shaped  Transversely oval /Flat bowl 
Sacrum  Sacral angle (SA)more than 90°  SA more than 90° Sacral angle less than 90° SA more than 90°
Sidewalls  Straight or slightly divergent  Straight or divergent  Convergent  Divergent 
Ischial spines  Not prominent  Not prominent  Prominent  Not prominent 
Subpubic angle   Wide (85°)  Slightly narrow  Narrow  Very wide (more than 90°) 
Position  Occipitolateral or oblique occipitoanterior  Direct occipito- anterior or posterior  Occipitolateral or oblique occipitoposterior  Occipitolateral 
Diameter of engagement  Transverse or oblique  Anteroposterior  Transverse or oblique  Transverse 
Delivery  No difficulty   More incidence of face-to-pubis delivery  a/w deep transverse arrest. Difficult delivery with an increased chance of perineal injuries  No difficulty

questions.text: What is the pathological basis for the given skin finding?
questions.solution:
The image is suggestive of vitiligo. The pathological basis of vitiligo is the loss of melanocytes.

Vitiligo is a common form of localized depigmentation. It is characterized by milky‐white sharply demarcated macules. It is an acquired condition resulting from the autoimmune destruction of dopa-positive melanocytes in the basal layer of the epidermis.

Vitiligo can begin at any age but in the majority of cases becomes apparent in the third decade. The prevalence is most probably the same in both sexes or a slight female preponderance.

Electron microscopy studies confirm the loss of melanocytes. Wood's lamp examination shows milky-white fluorescence.

Koebner phenomenon defined as the development of lesions at sites of trauma to uninvolved skin of patients with cutaneous diseases is a well‐known phenomenon in vitiligo.

questions.text: An 18 year old girl presents with a history of low-grade fever, weight loss, abdominal pain and amenorrhoea for six months. On examination, a pelvic mass is felt on the left side and signs of ascites are positive. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This female with a 6 months chronic history of symptoms along with the presence of a palpable abdominopelvic mass suggests genital tuberculosis. 

Genital tuberculosis commonly affects women in the reproductive age group. It presents with menstrual irregularities such as amenorrhoea, menorrhagia, dysmenorrhoea, pelvic pain. Non specific symptoms like fever and weight loss are also present. It affects fallopian tube causing infertility, tubo-ovarian masses, hydrosalpinx, pyosalpinx. Pelvic and abdominal peritoneum is often involved with multiple tubercles, ascites and abdominal masses.

Other options:

Option A: Submucous fibroid presents with menorrhagia, dyspareunia, pelvic pain, infertility or recurrent pregnancy loss.

Option B: Ovarian malignancy can also present with symptoms like abdominal fullness, bloating, nausea, abdominal distention, early satiety, fatigue, change in bowel movements, urinary symptoms, back pain, dyspareunia, weight loss, palpable pelvic mass or ascites . But this patient's young age and a chronic course of 6 month is unlikely to be a malignancy.

Option C: Ectopic pregnancy presents as amenorrhoea followed by an acute symptoms of vaginal bleeding and pelvic pain in a reproductive age women. It does not have a long course of 6 months and other symptoms seen in this girl.

questions.text: Progestasert releases ______
questions.solution:
Progestasert releases 65 μg of progesterone/ day

Progestasert:

  • Progestasert is a T-shaped device carrying 38 mg of progesterone in silicon oil reservoir in the vertical stem. It releases 65 mcg of the hormone per day.
  • The hormone released in the uterus forms a thick plug of mucus at the cervical os which prevents penetration by the sperms and thus exerts an added contraceptive effect.
  • Menstrual problems like menorrhagia and dysmenorrhoea noticed with Copper T are less with this device (40% reduction). It is expensive and requires yearly replacement.
  • A new device, levonova, contains 60 mg of levonorgestrel (LNG) and releases the hormone in very low doses (20 mcg/day). It is thus longer acting (5 years) and has a low pregnancy rate of 0–3 per 100 woman years.
  • However, the incidence of ectopic pregnancy is sixfold to ninefold higher in women who do become pregnant with progestogen IUCD as compared to failures amongst Copper T users. It can be safely recommended for nursing mothers.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best sign to indicate adequate growth in an infant with a birth weight of 2.8 kg?

choices.text: Increase in length of 25 centimeters in the first year
Weight gain of 300 grams per month till 1 year
Anterior fontanelle closure by 6 months of age
Weight under 75th percentile and height under 25th percentile

questions.solution:
The best sign to indicate adequate growth in an infant is an increase in length of 25 centimeters in the first year. The growth velocity is the rate of increase in height in one year and varies with age.

The average growth velocity is 25 cm/year in the first year (birth-12 months) and an infant will be 75 cm tall at 1 year. The height velocity is 10 cm/year from 12-24 months and at 2 years, the height is 90 cm. The height velocity is 8 cm/year from 24-36 months. At 4 years, the child is 100 cm tall. After this, the child gains about 6 cm every year until 12 years. 

If growth velocity is lower than expected for age, the child is likely to be suffering from a pathological cause of short stature.

Other options:

Option B: During the first 3 months of age, the weight gain is about 20-40 grams per day. From 4 months of age till 1 year of age, the weight gain is about 400 grams per month. The weight of an infant doubles his birth weight at 5 months of age and triples at 1 year of age and quadruples at 2 years of age.

Option C: The anterior fontanelle closes by 18 months of age.

Option D: According to WHO growth charts, weight under the 75th percentile and height under the 25th percentile do not indicate adequate growth.

questions.text: Which of the following curve corresponds to brain growth?
questions.solution:
The curve corresponding to brain growth is B

Brain growth occurs during the later part of fetal life and first two years after birth. The head is around 65-70% of adult size at birth and reaches 90% by the age of 2 years. 

Other options:

Option A: Lymphoid growth is prominent in the mid-childhood. It peaks at 4–8 years when the lymphoid tissue overgrows and may appear to be larger than that adult. This can be evident in the form of enlarged tonsils and palpable lymph nodes that regresses and subsequently reach adult size.

Option C: General body growth shows an S-shaped curve. It is rapid during the fetal period and the first 3–4 years. It is steady in the following period, followed by a growth spurt during puberty. Later, it slows down considerably.

Option D: Gonadal growth stays dormant during childhood and shows a rise with the onset of puberty.

questions.text: Identify the grip in the image given below:
questions.solution:
The Leopold's third maneuver is also called the Pawlik’s grip. It is performed by grasping with the thumb and fingers, the lower portion of the maternal abdomen just above the symphysis pubis. If the presenting part is not engaged, a movable mass will be felt.

Obstetric grips (Leopold maneuvers)

  1. Fundal grip (1st Leopold)
  2. Lateral/umbilical grip (2nd Leopold)
  3. 1st pelvic grip /Pawlik grip (3rd Leopold)
  4. 2nd pelvic grip (4th Leopold)

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presented with bleeding per vagina. She attained menopause at the age of 47. Examination findings were significant for post-menopausal bleeding. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
In this woman presenting with post-menopausal bleeding and normal external examination, the next step is to perform a transvaginal ultrasound to look for endometrial thickness.

Postmenopausal bleeding is diagnosed when there is bleeding per vagina after 6 months of amenorrhoea after the age of 40 (menopausal age). 

Causes of postmenopausal bleeding include: 

  • Genital tract trauma 
  • Cervical erosion, inflammation, polyp, ulcer, or cervical carcinoma.
  • Uterus - endometritis, endometrial hyperplasia, endometrial carcinoma, polyp, or sarcoma
  • Ovarian tumours such as Brenner tumor, granulosa cell tumor 
  • Blood dyscrasia
  • Urinary tract trauma, bladder carcinoma
  • Hemorrhoid, anal fissures, and rectal cancers are confused as bleeding per vagina
  • Use of estrogens as hormone replacement therapy, tamoxifen.

A woman presenting with post-menopausal bleeding should be first evaluated by taking a complete history and adequate examination. If there is growth on the cervix, biopsy is taken suspecting carcinoma. If the cervix looks normal, a transvaginal ultrasound and Pap smear is done.

The image below gives a summary of the evaluation of postmenopausal bleeding, as per the FOGSI guidelines.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of small cell carcinoma of the lung is diagnosed with the syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH). It is characterized by:
questions.solution:
The syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH) is associated with increased urinary excretion of sodium, thereby leading to euvolemic hyponatremia.

Small cell lung cancer is commonly associated with SIADH due to the ectopic release of antidiuretic hormone. 

The excess ADH secreted leads to the gain of water. This stimulates baroreceptors to release atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP). ANP leads to the loss of water and salt with urine sodium level is > 20 mEq/L in these patients.

Thus, the level of water reaches a steady-state (euvolemia) but the urinary loss of sodium continues to occur giving rise to hyponatremia.

Clinical features of SIADH 

  • Euvolemia: No signs of dehydration
  • Hyponatremia: Na less than 135mEq/L
  • Inappropriately elevated urine osmolality (less than 150mosm/Kg)
  • Excessive urine sodium excretion (more than 30 mEq/L) 
  • Decreased serum osmolality (less than 280mosm/Kg)

Laboratory features

  • Hyponatremia (Na less than 135 mEq/L) 
  • B.U.N. and serum uric acid falls because of plasma dilution and increased excretoin of nitrogenous products
  • Serum potassium and bicarbonate levels are normal in SIADH 
  • Low serum osmolality 

Related Pearl: Causes of SIADH

Neoplasms

Carcinomas

  • Lung
  • Duodenum
  • Pancreas
  • Ovary
  • Bladder, ureter

Other neoplasms

  • Thymoma
  • Mesothelioma
  • Bronchial adenoma
  • Carcinoid
  • Gangliocytoma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma

Head trauma (closed and penetrating)

  • Pneumonia
  • Abscess
  • Cavitation (aspergillosis)
  • Tuberculosis
  • Meningitis, Encephalitis
  • AIDS

Vascular

  • Cerebrovascular occlusions, haemorrhage
  • Cavernous sinus thrombosis

Neurologic

  • Guillain-Barre syndrome
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Delirium tremens
  • Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
  • Hydrocephalus
  • Psychosis
  • Peripheral neuropathy

Congenital malformations

  • Pneumothorax
  • Positive-pressure respiration

Drugs

  • Serotonin reuptake inhibitors

  • Nicotine

questions.text: Among the given women, the best candidate for the role of accredited social health activist (ASHA) is a 25–45-year-old woman who is ______.

choices.text: Unmarried with education up to the 10th standard
Married with education up to the 5th standard
Unmarried with education up to the 5th standard
A widow with education up to the 10th standard

questions.solution:
The correct answer is option D, woman who is a widow with education up to the 10th standard.

An ASHA is a trained female community health activist and a resident woman of the village with a formal education of at least up to 8th grade. She should preferably be in the age group of 25 to 45 years (married/divorced/widow) and have qualities such as good communication skills and leadership skills. The general norm of selection recommends having one ASHA for 1000 population, but in tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm could be relaxed to one ASHA per habitation.

 Roles of ASHA:

  • To create awareness and provide information to the community on determinants of health such as nutrition, basic sanitation, and hygienic practices
  • To counsel women on birth preparedness, the importance of safe delivery, breast-feeding and complementary feeding, immunization, and contraception
  • To counsel women on the prevention of common infections including reproductive tract infection/sexually transmitted infection 
  • To mobilize the community and help them in accessing health and health-related services.
  • To arrange and escort pregnant women and children requiring treatment/admission to the nearest pre-identified health facility
  • To inform sub-center/primary health center about the births and deaths in her village and any unusual health problems/disease outbreaks in the community
  • To promote the construction of household toilets under the total sanitation campaign

questions.text: Identify the neurological test being performed.
questions.solution:
The image shows extensor plantar response, which is a positive Babinski sign.
 
The normal response to uncomfortable or painful cutaneous stimulation of the file of the foot includes plantar flexion of the toes. This can be accompanied by flexion withdrawal of the limb. If there is an upper motor neuron lesion affecting the leg being tested, there will be an extensor plantar response, which is a positive Babinski sign. The minimum extensor response to be looked for is at least the extension of the great toe. It can be accompanied by fanning of other tows and contraction of the tensor fascia lata. Other features which may be seen in UMN lesions are spasticity of the leg, pathologically brisk reflexes, and ankle clonus.
 
The below image shows the positive and negative Babinski signs.

The image below shows a positive Babinski sign in an adult, which is abnormal and indicative of a UMN lesion. 

In infants whose corticospinal tracts are still underdeveloped, dorsiflexion of the great toe and fanning of other toes is a normal response to scratching of the sole of the foot. The image below shows an extensor response in an infant, which is normal.

questions.text: Appropriate sized endotracheal tube for an adult is _______.
questions.solution:
Appropriate sized endotracheal tube for an adult is 7.5 mm.

Size of an endotracheal tube usually refers to the internal diameter in mm.

Usually a 7-7.5 mm is used for women and an 8-8.5 mm ETT is used for men.

Related Pearl: Different sizes of the Endotracheal tube

Age Internal diameter(mm) Length(cm)
Full term infant 3.5    12
Child 4  + (Age/4) 

12 + (Age/2) [orotracheal]

14 + (Age/2)[nasotracheal]
Adult female 7.0 - 7.5      20-22
Adult male 7.5  - 9     22-24

questions.text: The most common type of conjoined twins among the given options is _______
questions.solution:
The most common type of conjoined twins among the given options is thoracophagus.

Based on the parts of the body joined, they are of the following types:

  • Ventral
    • Rostral
      • Omphalopagus (abdomen)
      • Thoracopagus (upper chest)
      • Cephalopagus (head)
    • Caudal
      • Ischiopagus (conjoined spines at 180 angles)
    • Lateral
      • Paraphagus (side-by-side fusion with a shared pelvis)
  • Dorsal
    • Craniopagus (skull)
    • Rachipagus (vertebral arches)
    • Pyopagus (pelvis)

Note: The most common type of conjoined twins is parapagus. Since the parapagus is not mentioned in the options, the thoracopagus is the most common among the given options.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with bluish discoloration of the skin and mucous membranes. All of the following findings may be responsible for the given symptoms except:
questions.solution:
Cyanosis is not seen when deoxygenated haemoglobin is 2 gm/dL, it becomes apparent when the concentration of deoxygenated/reduced haemoglobin exceeds 5 gm/dL.

Cyanosis is the bluish discolouration of the skin and mucous membranes. Cyanosis is caused by deoxygenated haemoglobin and abnormal haemoglobin. Oxygen might not reach haemoglobin in an adequate or sufficient amount.

Cyanosis is detectable with methemoglobin ≥ 1.5 gm% and/or sulfhemoglobin ≥ 0.5 gm%.

Central cyanosis is detectable when the oxygen saturation falls to 85%. In dark-skinned people, it may be detectable at an oxygen saturation of 75%.

The types of cyanosis are:

Central cyanosis Peripheral cyanosis

Due to diminished arterial oxygen saturation/presence of abnormal hemoglobin derivative.

Due to diminished peripheral blood flow.

Mucous membranes and skin are both affected

 Mucous membranes of the oral cavity or those beneath the tongue are spared.

Decreases after O2 supplementation

 Does not decrease after O2 supplementation

questions.text: Among the following, what is the most common location of aortic aneurysms?

choices.text: Proximal to the origin of renal arteries
Proximal to the origin of celiac arteries
Between the origins of celiac and renal arteries
Distal to the origin of renal artery

questions.solution:
Abdominal aortic aneurysms are much more common than thoracic aneurysms and the most common location is the infra-renal aorta. 

An asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm in an otherwise fit patient should be considered for repair if >55 mm in diameter (measured by ultrasonography). The annual incidence of rupture rises from 1% or less in aneurysms that are <55 mm in diameter to a significant level of nearly 25% in those that are 70 mm in diameter.

questions.text: A 62-year-old nulliparous female who is on hormone replacement therapy developed abdominal pain. On examination, a non-tender right adnexal mass was palpable. She underwent laparotomy and the resected ovaries are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario in a 62-year-old female with a larger, irregular and solid tumor growth with cystic spaces and necrosis is suggestive of ovarian carcinoma.

The risk factors of ovarian carcinoma are:

  • Low parity
  • Infertility
  • Unopposed estrogen therapy 
  • Obesity
  • Smoking 

Note: Hormone replacement therapy does not provide protection against the development of a borderline ovarian tumor.

Difference between benign and malignant tumours of the ovary:

  Benign Malignant
Examination

Unilateral, cystic, well-defined and mobile.

No ascites
(except in Meigs syndrome.)

No nodules in the abdomen or pouch of Douglas

Bilateral and solid, fixed.

Ascites may be present.

Metastatic nodules may be felt per abdomen. Nodules in the pouch of Douglas
USG

Cystic well-defined with or without echoes.

No ascites
(except in Meigs syndrome)

Solid and bilateral fixed with internal echoes.

Ascites may be present.

Metastatic nodules may be seen
Doppler ultrasound No increased vascularity Increased vascularity
Operative findings

Well-defined ovarian cystic or a solid tumour.

No ascites or metastatic nodule. Often mobile

Fixed solid tumour, often bilateral—with blood-stained ascites.

Metastatic growth over the omentum and peritoneal
cavity.

Lymph nodes may be enlarged

 

Complications of an ovarian tumor:

  • Torsion
  • Rupture 
  • Hemorrhage 
  • Infection
  • Pseudomyxoma peritoneum
  • Malignancy

Other options: 

Option A: There is no proper entity as Nodular carcinoma of the ovary

Option B: Chocolate cysts are seen in endometriosis involving the ovary. The cysts form secondary to endometriotic implants in the ovarian stroma that bleed periodically and undergo shedding.

Option C: Fibroids are benign growth of smooth muscles of the uterus and not the ovary.

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

I. Common epithelial tumors

  • Serous tumors
  • Mucinous tumors
  • Endometrioid tumors
  • Clear cell 
  • Brenner tumors (transitional cell tumors)
  • Seromucinous
  • Undifferentiated carcinoma
II. Sex cord-stromal tumors:
  • Pure stromal cell tumors- Fibroma, Thecoma, Leydig cell tumor, Steroid cell tumor
  • Pure sex cord tumors- Granulosa cell tumor (Adult/Juvenile), Sertoli cell tumor
  • Mixed sex cord-stromal tumors- Sertoli–Leydig cell tumors

III. Germ cell tumors:

  • Dysgerminoma
  • Endodermal sinus tumor (Yolk sac tumor)
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Polyembryoma
  • Non-gestational choriocarcinoma
  • Teratoma (Mature/immature)
  • Mixed forms

IV. Gonadoblastoma

  • Pure
  • Mixed with dysgerminoma or other germ cell tumors

V. Soft tissue tumors not specific to ovary
VI. Miscellaneous tumors
VII. Secondary (metastatic) tumors
VIII. Tumor-like conditions

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the active management of third stage of labor to prevent post partum haemorrhage (PPH)?

choices.text: Delayed clamping, cutting and ligation of cord

questions.solution:
According to the latest guidelines, uterine massage is no longer a core component of Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL) that is performed for the prevention of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH).

AMTSL is recommended by the WHO to prevent postpartum hemorrhage. It includes:

  • Injecting uterotonics within 1 minute of delivery of the baby or immediately after delivery of the anterior shoulder: Most important step, Oxytocin 10 IU im/iv infusion is the preferred uterotonic. 
  • Delayed cord clamping: Done within 1-3 mins of delivery
  • Delivery of placenta by controlled cord traction: Modified Brandt Andrews technique
  • Intermittent assessment of uterine tone: Done every 15 mins for 2 hours


Uterine massage or fundal massage is not recommended as an intervention to prevent PPH in women who have already received prophylactic uterotonics such as oxytocin (core component of AMTSL). Hence, it is now an optional component of AMTSL that is done in patients with uterine atony as a part of the management of PPH.
  

Note: In the event that uterine atony is diagnosed during the assessment of uterine tone, uterine massage can be performed to control PPH.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male patient presented to the emergency room with severe chest and back pain. Contrast-enhanced CT revealed a Stanford type B aortic dissection. What would be the initial management in this case?
questions.solution:
The initial management of a patient presenting with Stanford type B aortic dissection is the administration of anti-hypertensives.

Aortic dissection is initiated by an intimal tear and most commonly occurs in middle-aged and elderly hypertensive patients. Clinically, patients present with tearing intrascapular pain.

Classification of aortic dissection:

Acute aortic dissection can be classified in two ways: the original DeBakey system, which is based on the location of the proximal tear and distal extent of the dissection flap, and the Stanford system, which is based only on the location of the proximal tear. 

Site of dissection DeBakey Stanford
Both ascending and descending aorta Type I Type A
Only ascending aorta and arch of the aorta Type II Type A

Descending aorta distal to the subclavian artery

Type IIIa

Limited to the thoracic aorta

 Type B

Type IIIb

Extends to the abdominal aorta

Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is the investigation of choice in a hemodynamically unstable patient. In hemodynamically stable patients, the diagnosis is established with a contrast-enhanced CT scan. The characteristic diagnostic finding is a double-lumen aorta. 

Treatment options:

Ascending aortic dissection that includes Stanford Type A (DeBakey Types I and II) requires surgical intervention once the patient's blood pressure is stabilized.

Descending aortic dissection that includes Stanford Type B (DeBakey Type III) is initially best managed nonoperatively by antihypertensive drugs. Surgical intervention is indicated in complicated cases if the pain increases (signaling impending rupture) or when there is evidence of malperfusion of organs or neurological symptoms.

questions.text: The fracture seen in the Xray given below is?
questions.solution:
The X-ray reveals an oblique fracture in the lower third of radius with dislocation of the distal radio-ulnar joint, which is suggestive of Galeazzi's fracture. 

In Galeazzi's fracture, the radial bone is fractured at the junction of middle and distal third with subluxation or dislocation of distal radio-ulnar joint. 

Complications include :

  • Malunion
  • Nonunion
  • Entrapment of extensor carpi ulnaris tendon in distal radio-ulnar joint

Option B: Monteggia fracture: It is the fracture of shaft of ulna with dislocation of proximal radio-ulnar joint

Option C: Smith's fracture: It is also known as "Reverse Colle's fracture". It is the fracture of the distal radius with palmar angulation of the distal bone fragment.

Option D: Colle's fracture: It is the fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar displacement.

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius.

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of the ulnar bone.

questions.text: As per the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (Amendment) Bill, 2021,  which of the following statement is incorrect regarding the induction of MTP?

choices.text: Opinion of two providers is required for termination of pregnancy of 20-24 weeks
Upper gestational limit is not applicable in case of substantial foetal abnormalities
Upper limit for termination of pregnancy is 24 weeks in case of contraception failure
Misoprostol is best administered by mucosal route than oral route

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement is the upper limit for termination of pregnancy is 24 weeks in case of contraception failure. It is only done up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure. 

Until 20 weeks of gestation opinion of one doctor and opinion of two doctors for 20-24 weeks of gestation. In case of any fetal abnormalities, the upper gestation limit is not applied.

The features of the MTP bill 2021 are, the upper gestation limit is increased from 20 to 24 weeks of gestation for special categories of women including survivors of rape, differently-abled women, and minors.

Mucosal misoprostol administration has increased efficacy and minimizes gastrointestinal side effects and is now preferred over the prior oral administration. The mucosal route includes buccal, sublingual, and vaginal.

Related Pearl: Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act - MTP Act 1971

MTP Act with 2021 amendments 

Indications:

  • Therapeutic - to save the life of the mother
  • Eugenic - to prevent the risk of the child being born with serious mental or physical abnormality i.e. first-trimester viral infections, teratogenic drug intake, radiation exposure
  • Humanitarian - pregnancy resulted from rape or incest
  • Social - pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives 

Rules:

  • Only a registered medical practitioner who is qualified (one who has assisted in the performance of 25 cases of MTP in a recognized hospital) can terminate a pregnancy.
  • MTP should be carried out in a government or government-recognized hospital. Private hospitals may take up MTP if they obtain a license from the chief medical officer of the district.
  • The termination of pregnancy by a person, who is not a registered medical practitioner (the person concerned), or in an unrecognised hospital (administrative head) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 2 years, but which may extend to 7 years. 

Consent:

The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. 

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.

Opinion of doctors:

  • Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion
  • 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion
  • For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state

Upper limit of MTP:

  • Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations
  • Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure (any female with her partner)
  • At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board

Confidentiality:

A register for recording the details of MTP must be kept for at least 5 years. The patient's name must not be entered, only the reference number is used. Unlawful disclosure of patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment ± fine.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of lower extremity weakness. He initially noticed difficulty climbing the stairs and now he is unable to stand. He gives a history of bloody diarrhea a few weeks ago. The physician suspects a case of Guillain- Barre syndrome.  Which of the following are expected to be elevated in the CSF of this patient?
questions.solution:
Protein levels are elevated (100-1000mg/dl) in the CSF of a patient with Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS).

The CSF cell counts are usually normal. Pleocytosis (presence of an abnormally large number of lymphocytes in the cerebrospinal fluid) is usually not seen in GBS. Albuminocytologic dissociation, which is an elevation in CSF protein without an elevation in white blood cells, is characteristic in GBS.

Causes of albuminocytologic dissociation

  • Guillain-Barre Syndrome
  • Spinal cord tumours

questions.text: This instrument is least useful in ________
questions.solution:
The instrument given in the above image is a proctoscope.

Due to pain, digital rectal examination and anoscopy are not performed immediately in acute anal fissure, but reserved for later, when the symptoms resolve or the patient is in the operating room.

questions.text: Which of the following is a component of the scheme depicted by the logo given below?
questions.solution:
National Health Protection Mission is a component of the Ayushman Bharat scheme.

Ayushman Bharat-National Health Protection Mission (AB-NHPM) aims to build a comprehensive need-based health care service and targets to build a 'New India 2022'. Its components are:

  • Creation of 1,50,000 Health and Wellness Centres- these centres will provide Comprehensive Primary Health Care (CPHC), covering both maternal and child health services and non-communicable diseases, including free essential drugs and diagnostic services. 
  • National Health Protection Mission (NHPM) provides health protection cover to poor and vulnerable families, screening for non-communicable diseases, and follow-up of hospitalization cases among others.

Beneficiary Level: 

  • The government provides health insurance cover of up to Rs. 5,00,000 per family per year.
  • All families listed in the Socio-Economic Caste Census (SECC) database as per defined criteria will be covered. No cap on family size and age of members.
  • Priority to a girl child, women, and senior citizens.
  • Free treatment is available at all public and empanelled private hospitals in times of need.
  • Covers secondary and tertiary care hospitalization.
  • 1,350 medical packages covering surgery, medical and daycare treatments, cost of medicines, and diagnostics.
  • All pre-existing diseases are covered. Hospitals cannot deny treatment.
  • Cashless and paperless access to quality health care services.
  • Hospitals will not be allowed to charge any additional money from beneficiaries for the treatment.
  • Can reach out for information, assistance, complaints, and grievances to a 24X7 helpline number.

Ayushman Bharat Diwas is being celebrated across the country on April 30.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with abrupt onset of fever, oliguria, nausea, cola-colored urine, and puffy eyes. Two weeks before the onset of symptoms the child had been treated for complaints of sore throat. Which of the following findings will be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features with a history of sore throat two weeks prior to the onset of symptoms are suggestive of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). Red blood cells can be seen in the urine of these patients.

Children with this disease present with hematuria, red cell casts in the urine, cola-coloured urine, oliguria, hypertension, mild to moderate proteinuria, and edema.

It usually appears 1 to 4 weeks after a streptococcal infection of the pharynx or skin (impetigo). This disease is not commonly seen in children below three years of age.

PSGN is caused by immune complexes containing streptococcal antigens and specific antibodies, which are formed in situ.

Related Pearl: Nephrotic and nephritic syndromes

 

Nephrotic Syndrome

Nephritic Syndrome (Glomerulonephritis)

Primary pathology

Damage and dysfunction of glomerular filtration barrier, causing significant leakage of plasma proteins without much glomerular inflammation

Significant inflammatory injury of the glomerulus resulting in passage of RBCs, inflammatory cells & plasma proteins

The principal site of glomerular injury

 Visceral epithelial cell (Podocyte) Endothelial cells, glomerular basement membrane (GBM), Mesangial cells, Parietal epithelial cells (>Crescents)

Hallmark:

Heavy Proteinuria: 3.5 g/24 h or Urine protein:creatinine ratio >3)

Edema

Lipiduria, Hyperlipidemia

Microscopic hematuria

Hypertension

Hypercoagulability                                                    

Hallmark:

Hematuria (RBC casts/dysmorphic RBCs)

Varying degrees of proteinuria and pyuria

Renal dysfunction

Hypertension

Associated Glomerular pathology

Minimal change disease (Primary and secondary)

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) (Primary and secondary)

Membranous-nephropathy (Primary and secondary)

Diabetic nephropathy

Amyloidosis

Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (crescentic)

IgA nephropathy (Berger disease)

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis

Alport syndrome

These syndromes, however, are not mutually exclusive. Some glomerular diseases may progress from one pattern to another or may present with considerable overlap between them, as a nephritic–nephrotic syndrome; features of nephrotic syndrome can concurrently occur with any form of nephritic syndrome but are most commonly seen with diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (seen in systemic lupus erythromytosus) and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

Related Pearl: Glomerular Pathology in Renal Diseases

Nephritic syndrome:

Note:

questions.text: A patient comes with a blood pressure of 160/100 mmHg and left-sided facial paralysis and weakness for 8 hours. Her CT is shown below. What would be your next step?
questions.solution:
This patient with sudden onset hemiparesis and a normal CT could have a transient ischemic attack or an ischemic stroke. The next step for this patient would be observation and monitoring.

Non-contrast CT(NCCT) is the imaging modality of choice in patients with acute stroke. CT may appear normal for the first few hours and the infarct may not appear until 24-48 hours. Diffusion-weighted MRI(DWMRI) is more sensitive to detecting early brain infarction. 

Initial treatment of acute ischemic stroke includes maintaining the patient's airway, breathing, and circulation. Complications such as hyperglycemia, hypoglycemia, or fever should be treated if present.

Thrombolysis with alteplase is the first-line therapy for acute ischemic stroke and should be initiated within 4.5 hours of symptom onset. Since this patient arrived 8 hours later which is outside of window period, the appropriate management would be observation and monitoring. Endovascular mechanical thrombectomy is done in patients who do not respond to thrombolytic therapy or in whom thrombolysis is contraindicated. Oral aspirin is recommended for the acute treatment of ischemic stroke.

Labetalol, nicardipine, and clevidipine are the first-line anti-hypertensive agents used in the acute phase of stroke. If the patient is to receive thrombolytic therapy, maintain BP ≤185/110mmHg. If not, BP should not be treated acutely unless it is more than 220/120 mmHg. BP should be lowered cautiously by only 15% in the first 24 hours in order to preserve perfusion to the ischemic penumbra.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with progressive swelling of his right wrist associated with a dull aching pain. The orthopedician elicits tenderness on firm palpation of the swelling. The following findings are seen on X-ray. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is osteoclastoma/giant cell tumor.

Osteoclastoma is a bone tumour with varying growth potential. It can be either benign/malignant, though it is more commonly benign. It is seen in patients who are 20-40 years of age. The commonly affected sites are the lower end of the femur, the upper end of the tibia, and the distal end of the radius.

Patients present with swelling and vague pain. Pathological fractures may also be seen. On examination, firm palpation can elicit tenderness. 

Radiologically, soap bubble appearance is seen due to interspersed lytic lesions and bone remnants. Intralesional curettage of the tumour is the common approach to management.

Other options

Option A: Chondrosarcoma is a malignant bone tumour arising from the cartilage cells. It may arise in any bone but is common in flat bones such as the scapula, pelvis, and ribs.

Option B: Osteosarcoma is a highly malignant primary bone tumor. Common sites are the lower end of the femur, the upper end of the tibia, and the upper end of the humerus. Patients present with a history of pain followed by swelling. Radiologically, periosteal reaction, sunburst appearance, and Codman's triangle can be seen. The characteristic sunburst appearance can be seen below.

Option D: Osteochondroma is a common benign tumour of the bone. The tumour stops enlarging in size once there is a cessation of growth at the epiphyseal plate. It is usually seen in adolescents who present with painless swelling around a joint, usually the knee. X-ray shows a well-defined exostosis as shown below.
