questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant woman came with a history of thyroid swelling. FNAC report was suggestive of papillary carcinoma thyroid and the nodule was “cold” on scan. Which of the following will not be a treatment option for her?

choices.text: Total Thyroidectomy plus Lymph node dissection

questions.solution:
Radioiodine ablation of thyroid is contraindicated in pregnant women due to risk of radiation exposure to the fetus. 

Therapeutic uses for Radioactive Iodine

  1. In primary thyrotoxicosis 
  2. In autonomous toxic nodules, it is useful as remaining gland still will function adequately after radiotherapy.
  3. In follicular carcinoma of thyroid, after total thyroidectomy, if there are secondaries elsewhere in the body, as in bones or lungs, then I131 is given.

questions.text: Whipple’s triad is seen in which of the following diseases:
questions.solution:
Whipple’s triad is seen in patients with insulinoma.

It consists of the following three features:

  • Symptoms of hypoglycemia
  • Low plasma glucose levels at the time of symptoms
  • Reversal of hypoglycemic symptoms with ingestion of carbohydrates within 15 minutes

Whipple’s disease – Malabsorption by Tropheryma whippeli

Whipple’s operation – Carcinoma pancreas

questions.text: Which of the following is the treatment of some dehydration in a child with severe acute malnutrition?

choices.text: Half-strength WHO low-osmolarity ORS with added glucose and potassium
Full-strength standard WHO low-osmolarity ORS with added glucose and potassium

questions.solution:
The treatment of some dehydration in a child with severe acute malnutrition is half-strength WHO low-osmolarity ORS with glucose and potassium.

ReSoMal is another oral rehydration salt or ORS for severely malnourished children. It is used in in-patient centres for the treatment of children with severe acute malnutrition. ReSoMal contains a higher amount of glucose (125mmol/L) and a lower amount of sodium (45mmol/L) than the standard WHO-ORS.

Full-strength, standard WHO low-osmolarity oral rehydration solution (75 mmol/L of sodium) should not be used for oral or nasogastric rehydration in children with severe acute malnutrition.

Intravenous therapy should be given only for severe dehydration and shock or if the enteral route cannot be used. IV fluids that can be used in these children are

  • Ringer lactate with 5% dextrose
  • Half-normal saline with 5% dextrose 
  • Half-strength Darrow solution with 5% dextrose.

questions.text: A patient is on magnesium sulfate therapy post-cesarean section for preeclampsia.  During her assessment after the 3rd maintenance dose, she has a respiratory rate of 8/min, a random blood glucose level of 240 mg/dL, oliguria, and a bilaterally absent knee reflex. Which of the following is the most appropriate way to manage this case?

choices.text: Stop magnesium therapy and give IV calcium gluconate
Stop magnesium therapy and give oral calcium gluconate
Give half dose magnesium therapy and IV calcium gluconate
Skip the next maintenance dose and follow up

questions.solution:
The next step in this patient with magnesium sulphate (MgSO4) toxicity is to stop magnesium therapy and give IV calcium gluconate.

MgSO4 is used as an anticonvulsant in the management of eclampsia and as prophylaxis in severe preeclampsia. The therapeutic level of magnesium in eclampsia is 4–7 mEq/L. MgSO4 has to be administered up to 24 hrs after the last seizure (in postpartum seizure) or delivery, whichever is later.

Signs suggestive of magnesium toxicity include:

  • Loss of deep tendon reflexes
  • Decreased respiratory rate <12/min
  • Urine output <30 mL/h
  • Chest pain and heart block 
  • Visual changes, flushing, muscle paralysis, and drowsiness

It is treated by stopping magnesium therapy and giving slow IV calcium gluconate 10 mL (10% solution) infusion. Fluid loading and forced diuresis are done and estimation of serum magnesium and creatinine levels. Before administering the maintenance dose of MgSO4, the above signs are checked. IM injections of magnesium sulfate are continued only under the following conditions:

  • The patellar reflex is present
  • Respiration is not depressed
  • Urine output >30 mL/h

 The two commonly used MgSO4 regimens are described below: 

Regimen

Loading Dose

Maintenance Dose

Intramuscular (Pritchard)

4 g (20% solution) IV over 3–5 minutes, followed by 10 g (50%) deep IM (5 g in each buttock)

5 g (50%) IM 4 hourly in the alternate buttock

Intravenous (Zuspan or Sibai)

4 g IV slow over 15–20 minute

1–2 g/h IV infusion

questions.text: Pseudodementia is associated with which of the following conditions
questions.solution:
Pseudodementia is a condition characterized by cognitive and functional impairment secondary to depression.

  • Dementia is defined as a disease process, which is marked by progressive cognitive impairment in clear consciousness. Ex: Dementia in Alzheimer's disease.
  • Pseudodementia occurs in depressed people who complain of impaired memory but, in fact, have a depressive disorder.

The following table shows differentiating clinical features between dementia and pseudodementia:

Dementia

Pseudodementia

Clinical Course and History

 

Onset can be dated only within broad limits

Onset can be dated precisely

Long duration and slow progression of symptoms

Short duration and rapid progression of symptoms

Usually, there is no history of previous psychiatric dysfunction

There is a history of previous psychiatric dysfunction.

Family is not aware of the patient's dysfunction and severity

Family is aware of the patient's dysfunction and severity

Complaints and clinical behaviour

The patients complain little of cognitive loss, and the complaints are often vague

The patients complain much of cognitive loss, and the complaints are detailed.

Usually labile affect

  

Severe depression on examination

Disability is concealed by the patient

Disability is emphasized by the patient

Patient highlights accomplishments

Patient highlights failures

They struggle to perform simple tasks and rely on notes or calendars etc.

They make little effort to perform even simple tasks

Social skills are often retained

Loss of social skills often early and prominent
Behaviour is compatible with the severity of cognitive dysfunction Behaviour is incongruent with the severity of cognitive dysfunction
Nocturnal accentuation of dysfunction common Nocturnal accentuation of dysfunction uncommon

Clinical Features Related to Memory, Cognitive, and Intellectual Dysfunctions

Patient makes errors on cognitive examination

‘Do not know’ answers are more frequent

Attention and concentration usually faulty

 Attention and concentration often well preserved

Memory loss for recent events usually more severe than for remote events

  

Memory loss for recent and remote events usually severe

Memory gaps for specific periods unusual. Confabulation may be present.

  Memory gaps are usually present. Confabulation is rare.

questions.text: What is the preferred treatment of uterine prolapse in a nulliparous woman who desires future pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Sling operations are recommended in cases of nulliparous prolapse for those who wish to retain menstrual and child-bearing function. Mackenrodt’s and uterosacral ligaments of the uterus are strengthened, by using nylon or Dacron tapes as slings. Abdominal sling operations include abdominal wall cervicopexy, Shirodkar’s sling operation, Khanna’s abdominal sling operation, Virkud's sling operation, and Joshi's sling operation.

A ring pessary is used for patients who cannot be surgically managed, such as pregnant patients, patients in puerperium, and very elderly women unfit for surgery. It is used in adjunct with pelvic floor physiotherapy. Pessaries provide mechanical support to the pelvic organs. The first step after fitting the pessary to check if the pessary is adequately retained is to ask the patient to perform Valsalva's manoeuvre or cough and see if the pessary is in place. After being placed, they need to be changed every 3 months. 

Related Pearl: Management of Uterine prolapse

Congenital/ Nulliparous (young) uterine prolapse: Sling/ cervicopexy

Uterovaginal uterine prolapse:

Age/condition Desire for pregnancy Desire for menstruation Surgery
<40 No Yes Fothergill's operation
>40 No No  Ward Mayo's vaginal hysterectomy
>60(medically unfit for hysterectomy)        -      - Le Forts repair
Prolapse during pregnancy /puerperium     -       - Ring Pessary

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute indication for a cesarean section?
questions.solution:
Among the following, vaginal stenosis is an absolute indication of a cesarean section(CS).

Cesarean is needed even with a dead fetus when vaginal delivery is not possible.
The following are the absolute indication:

  • Central placenta previa 
  • Contracted pelvis or cephalopelvic disproportion (absolute)
  • Pelvic mass causing an obstruction (cervical or broad ligament fibroid)
  • Advanced carcinoma cervix 
  • Vaginal atresia or stenosis

Relative indications for cesarean section are those where vaginal delivery may be possible but risks to the mother and/or baby are high. They are as follows:

  • Nonreassuring FHR
  • Dystocia- It may be due to a relatively large fetus (passenger), small pelvis (passage), or inefficient uterine contractions (power)
  • Antepartum hemorrhage: Placenta previa and abruptio placenta
  • Malpresentation: Breech, shoulder (transverse lie), brow
  • Previous cesarean delivery-a) When primary CS was due to recurrent indication (contracted pelvis), (b) Previous two CS,(c) Features of scar dehiscence, (d) Previous classical CS
  • Cephalopelvic disproportion (relative)
  • Failure to progress in labor
  • Hypertensive disorders: Severe pre-eclampsia, eclampsia— uncontrolled fits even with antiseizure therapy.

questions.text: A 51-year-old lady presents with complaints of a mass in the right breast. The examination finding is shown below. Fixed internal mammary and axillary lymph nodes are palpable on the same side. The mass is malignant without any metastasis. What is the TNM staging in this lady?
questions.solution:
This given clinical scenario in this woman with peau d’orange of the breast suggests her staging is T4b N3b M0

  • Tumour of any size with overlying skin involvement (Peau d'orange appearance) - T4b
  • Ipsilateral fixed internal mammary and axillary lymph nodes - N3b
  • No distant metastasis - M0

The term peau d’orange describes the orange-peel appearance of the skin. The dermal lymphatic blockade gives rise to edema in the breast. The sweat glands and hair follicles get buried due to the edema resulting in a typical orange peel appearance. Infiltration of the ligaments of Cooper results in dimpling of the skin. Infiltration of the lactiferous glands gives rise to retraction of the nipple. Spread into the chest wall results in fixation of the breast into the chest wall. This leads to restricted mobility of the breast

Note: LCIS (lobular carcinoma in situ) is considered as a benign condition and not included under Tis.

questions.text: Conn’s syndrome is associated with all of the following clinical features except
questions.solution:
In Conn’s syndrome, an underlying salt escape mechanism leads to the absence of pedal edema.

The volume expansion due to hypernatremia will lead to Right heart dilatation stimulating the release of Atrial Natriuretic Peptide (ANP). This will lead to the loss of water and balance the gain due to the influence of aldosterone.

Features of Primary hyperaldosteronism:

  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypertension
  • Metabolic alkalosis
  • Polyuria – Due to ANP
  • Polydipsia – As a consequence of polyuria
  • Muscle weakness
  • Decreased plasma renin levels

questions.text: A child presents with lesions as shown in the image below. He also complained of decreased vision at night. Which of the following dose of vitamin A prophylaxis given to children under the vitamin A distribution scheme in India could have prevented this condition?

choices.text: 2,00,000 IU  given yearly between the ages 1-6 years
1,00,000 IU  given yearly between the ages 1-6 years
1,00,000 IU  given 6-monthly between the ages 1-6 years
2,00,000 IU given 6-monthly between the ages 1-6 years

questions.solution:
The image above showing phrynoderma along with the history of decreased vision at the night suggests a likely diagnosis of vitamin A deficiency. Under the vitamin-A distribution scheme in India, 200,000 IU of vitamin A are given orally at 6-monthly intervals between the ages of 1 to 6 years.

Vitamin A deficiency is a major preventable cause of blindness in children. It can lead to mucocutaneous disease and result in various ocular complications, including blindness. The earliest sign of vitamin A deficiency is defective dark adaptation and night blindness (nyctalopia). Xerosis and scaling are commonly present in cutaneous findings. Phrynoderma, which is characterized by the presence of keratotic follicular papules over anterolateral thighs and posterolateral upper arms is also seen.

Treatment is done by administering 50,000–2,00,000 IU of daily vitamin A supplementation until clinical signs and symptoms resolve and serum retinol levels normalize. 

The image below shows a Bitot's spot(due to Vitamin A deficiency) seen as a foamy appearance on the surface of the conjunctiva.

Related Pearl: Vitamin-A supplementation & treatment of Vitamin-A deficiency

Vitamin A supplementation
Target group
6 to 11 months age
12 to 59 month of age (1yr to 5yr)
Dose
100,000 IU (oral)
200,000 IU (oral)
Frequency
Once
Every 4–6 months

 

Note: A total dose of 17 lakh IU given as per the following schedule:

  • 100,000 IU is given with measles vaccine at 9 months
  • 200,000 IU is given with DPT booster at 15–18 months
  • 200,000 IU is given every 6 months (till 5years of age)

 

Treatment of vitamin A deficiency
Age < 6 months 6-12 months > 1 year
Dose 50,000 IU 100,000 IU 200,000 IU

 

Note: Route of administration is oral, in the form of retinol palmitate.

questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic patient presents to you with severe pain and swelling of the left leg. He gives a history of sustaining a thorn prick to his left foot while hiking 5 days ago. The examination of his leg is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of cellulitis.

Cellulitis is a painful, diffuse infection of the dermis and the subcutaneous tissue. It is characterized by poorly demarcated areas of marked edema, dilated superficial capillaries, and extravasation of red blood cells and inflammatory cells into the dermis. Constitutional symptoms like fever and malaise are also present.

It is most commonly caused by beta-haemolytic Streptococci, Staphylococci, and Clostridium perfringens. The point of entry may be a traumatic or surgical wound. Lower limbs are the commonest site of cellulitis and any wound, including tinea pedis or bacterial infection, is a possible site of entry. The face is the next common site of infection.

Parenteral penicillin is the treatment of choice. Other regimens may include antistaphylococcal penicillins, cefazolin, ceftaroline, and ceftriaxone.

Other options:

Option A: Erysipelas is an infection of the superficial epidermis. It presents as an erythematous raised lesion with sharply demarcated edges that differentiate it from the surrounding skin. The given image shows erysipelas.

Option B: Lymphangitis will be evident with visible erythema tracking along lymphatic channels.

Option D: Necrotizing fasciitis is a rapidly progressive necrosis of the subcutaneous tissues and fascia. The source of the infection is either the skin following trauma or a surgical incision. Diabetes mellitus is the most common comorbidity associated with the condition. 

Local symptoms and signs are pain, erythema, edema, warmth, crepitus, blisters, bullae, greyish drainage (dishwater pus), necrosis, and gangrene. Systemic features are fever, tachycardia, tachypnea, shock, coagulopathy, and multiorgan failure. 

Treatment involves appropriate intravenous antibiotics with urgent radical surgical debridement.

The following image shows surgical debridement being done for a case of necrotizing fasciitis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female patient with a history of breast and ovarian cancers in her siblings underwent genetic testing. She is found to have a mutation in the BRCA1 gene.  She is at the risk of developing:
questions.solution:
Individuals with BRCA1 mutations are likely to develop triple receptor-negative and high-grade breast carcinomas.

Related Pearl: Comparison between BRCA 1 and BRCA 2:

Both BRCA1 and BRCA2 are tumor suppressor genes.

Carcinoma breast occurs at an earlier age and is bilateral and multicentric in inherited forms compared to sporadic cases.

  BRCA 1 BRCA 2
Location Long arm of chromosome 17  Long arm of chromosome 13
Differentiation Poorly differentiated Well-differentiated
Hormone receptor status ER/PR- Negative, Her-2 negative – triple negative ER/PR- Positive
Associated Cancers Breast, ovarian, colon, and prostate (lesser extent), Pancreas (lesser extent)  cancers Breast, ovarian, colon, prostate, pancreas, gall bladder, stomach cancers, and melanoma
Male breast carcinoma  Low association Increased risk
Fanconi’s anemia  Associated Associated
Medullary carcinoma Associated No association

 

Related Pearl: Breast Cancer Screening

Breast Cancer Screening*

Individuals are encouraged to conduct a risk assessment by 25 years of age. This helps classify them into average risk or increased risk groups.

Recommendations: 

  1. Average-risk (no known genetic or family history of breast cancer)
    • 25-39 years of age: clinical breast examination every 1-3 years; 
    • ≥ 40 years of age: clinical breast examination and mammogram annually
  2. Increased risk (positive family or genetic history of breast cancer)
    • Consult a healthcare professional every 6-12 months after 21 years of age
    • Annual mammogram or MRI from 25 years of age or 10 years prior to the age at which the youngest family member was diagnosed with breast cancer (whichever is earliest)
  3. Asymptomatic women with previously treated breast cancer
    • Consult a healthcare professional every 6-12 months
    • Annual mammogram
    • Annual MRI to be considered
  4. Mammogram and USG are not contraindicated in pregnant and breastfeeding women

High-risk patients for breast cancer:

  1. Women (or a first-degree relative) with a known BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation or TP53 or PTEN genes
  2. Two first-degree relatives with breast cancers with or without gene mutations
  3. Women with a history of chest irradiation between the ages of 10 and 30
  4. Women with previously biopsy-proven breast cancer
  5. Women with ≥ 20% lifetime risk for breast cancer based on breast cancer risk models

*According to NCCN 2022 guidelines

Almost all breast malignancies are adenocarcinomas and based on the expression of estrogen receptor and HER2 can be divided into three major biologic subgroups:

  • ER-positive HER2-negative tumors (50% to 65% of tumors) – range from well-differentiated cancers with low proliferative rates and few chromosomal changes to poorly differentiated cancers with high proliferative rates and large numbers of chromosomal rearrangements. All of these cancers express ER.
  • HER2-positive cancers - 10% to 20% of tumors, which may either be ER-positive or ER-negative.
  • ER-negative, HER2-negative carcinomas (triple-negative or basal-like)- are characterized by genomic instability, a high proliferative rate, and expression of many proteins typical of myoepithelial cells (e.g., basal keratins).

questions.text: A 21-year-old female presents to the clinic requesting liposuction. She feels she is obese and would like to get rid of the "excess fat". On further enquiry, she reveals a habit of eating high-calorie food multiple times a month which she later regrets and skipping meals at times. Her BMI is 23. An examination of her hands is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows calluses and pigmentation on knuckles, known as Russell's sign. The given clinical history of binge eating, body-image issues, Russell's sign along with a normal BMI is suggestive of bulimia nervosa.

Bulimia nervosa is an eating disorder, often seen in young women. It is characterized by binge-eating episodes, followed by inappropriate, compensatory measures to stop weight gain, like self-induced vomiting, laxative abuse, diuretics, enema, and emetic abuse. The calluses on hands form due to the repeated scraping of knuckles on the teeth, during self-induced vomiting. These binge-eating episodes occur at least once a week and are present for at least 3 months. The patient fears gaining weight and has a relentless drive to be thin. 

Treatment of bulimia nervosa:

  • Without comorbid mood disorders - fluoxetine, topiramate, CBT
  • With comorbid mood disorders - carbamazepine

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents to dermatology OPD with the given condition. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image is diagnostic of Melasma.

  • Melasma is the most common cause of facial melanosis and is manifested by hyperpigmented macules on the face which become more pronounced after sun exposure.
  • Hyper-melanosis affects mainly the upper lip, the malar regions, forehead, chin and mandible region.
  • It is more common in women (90%) and in ages between 20-40 years.
  • Melasma is frequently seen in women on oral contraceptives.
  • Melasma is more chronic and requires treatment with depigmenting agents like:
    • Hydroquinone (reduces tyrosinase activity)
    • Kojic acid (tyrosinase inhibitor)
    • Chemical peels
    • Kligman's triple combination- Topical hydroquinone + tretinoin + corticosteroid compound cream [First line]

Other Options:

  • The same facial melanosis in pregnant women is called Chloasma or mask of pregnancy. Only the terms used differ. Chloasma is very common in the 3rd trimester of pregnancy. Chloasma usually resolves after pregnancy.
  • Systemic Lupus Erythematosus: A well-demarcated erythematous butterfly rash over the malar eminences with sparing of the nasolabial folds. The image given below shows a malar rash.
  • Rosacea: Mainly involves the convexities of the face and presents as erythemato-telangiectatic type over the cheeks. The following image shows an image of the rash of rosacea.

questions.text: A patient suffers burns injury only to the ventral portion of the body as shown below. Calculate the percentage of burns in terms of body surface area.
questions.solution:
The percentage of burns in this person is around 28-30% of the body surface area.

Wallace's rule of nines is used in estimating medium to large burns in adults. It helps in the quick estimation of burns. In this, the total burn is calculated by dividing the body into areas of 9%. It is not accurate in children.

Accordingly, this patient has burns in the anterior thorax (9%) + anterior abdomen (9%)+ anterior part of both thighs (4.5%+4.5%)+ anterior part of upper arm (2.25%). This roughly totals 29.25%. Hence this patient has burns around 28-30% of the body surface area.

questions.text: A 56-year-old diabetic male presented with arthralgia and skin pigmentation. On examination, he was found to have hepatomegaly, arthropathy involving small joints, excessive skin pigmentation with characteristic slate-grey hue, and hypogonadism. What will be the best treatment for this disease?
questions.solution:
Phlebotomy is the best treatment for iron-overload states like hemochromatosis which is given in the clinical scenario above. One 500-mL unit of blood contains 200–250 mg of iron. Iron removal can be accomplished by weekly or twice-weekly phlebotomy of 500 mL.

With repeated phlebotomy, the following changes occur:

  • Liver decreases in size
  • Liver function improves
  • Hepatic fibrosis may decrease, but established cirrhosis is irreversible
  • Pigmentation of skin decreases
  • Cardiac failure may be reversed
  • Diabetes also improves in about 40% of patients.
  • There is little or no effect of arthropathy and hypogonadism. In some cases, arthropathy may even progress, despite therapy.

The goal is to reduce the serum ferritin levels to 50 - 100 ng/mL. Once the goal is reached, the phlebotomies may be done at appropriate intervals (usually, 3-4 times a year), required to maintain the serum ferritin levels at that level. 

Hemochromatosis is an autosomal recessive disease caused due to mutation in the HFE gene on chromosome 6. It is tightly linked to the HLA-A locus on chromosome 6p.

Pathogenesis:

The HFE protein is thought to play an important role in the process by which duodenal crypt cells sense body iron stores, leading in turn to increased iron absorption from the duodenum. A decrease in the synthesis or expression of hepcidin, the principal iron regulatory hormone, is also a key pathogenic factor. This excessively absorbed iron is primarily deposited in parenchymal organs such as the liver, pancreas and also heart, joints and endocrine organs.

Other features:

  • Hemochromatosis can also be acquired from iron overload due to hemolytic anaemia and transfusions.
  • It is associated with increased risk of Hepatocellular carcinoma.
  • Dilated Cardiomyopathy (DCM) is the most common manifestation of hemochromatosis. Hemochromatosis can also produce Restrictive cardiomyopathy but it is less common as compared to DCM. 

Other options:

Deferoxamine is used when phlebotomy is not well-tolerated. It is a chelating agent which removes 10–20 mg of iron per day when given parenterally.

Trientine and D penicillamine are chelating agents that bind to copper, and are used in the treatment of Wilson's disease.

questions.text: Identify the hysterosalpingogram.
questions.solution:
The image shows a normal hysterosalpingogram (HSG). Note both fallopian tubes are patent with a spill into the peritoneal cavity.

Other options

Option B: The HSG below has no peritoneal spillage on one side(marked with an arrow) with a normal spillage on the other: Filling defects. This is suggestive of a unilateral tubal blockade.

 

Option B: HSG showing bilateral dilated Fallopian tubes with no free spill suggestive of bilateral hydrosalpinx.

 

 

Option C: HSG showing bicornuate uterus/septate uterus.

questions.text: A 25-year-old G2A1 at 18 weeks of gestation came with complaints of leaking PV for the past 4 hours. On examination, membranes are ruptured and uterine contractions present. Which of the following sonographic findings is indicative of cervical incompetence in this patient _______

choices.text: Short cervix <25 mm and funelling of internal os >1cm
Short cervix >25 mm and funelling of internal os <1cm
Short cervix <35 mm and funelling of internal os <1cm
Short cervix >35mm and funelling of internal os >1cm

questions.solution:
Transvaginal ultrasound is the ideal method to follow up and detect cervical incompetence. Features of short cervix <25 mm and funnelling of internal os >1 cm is seen in cervical incompetence.

Cervical incompetence or insufficiency is a functional or anatomical impairment in the retentive power of the cervix (or internal os). It is characterized by repeated, mid-trimester painless cervical dilatation. It leads to the escape of amniotic fluid followed by painless expulsion of the products of conception.

In the inter-conceptional period, diagnosis is made with the passage of number 6-8 Hegar's dilator beyond the internal os without resistance or pain. Investigations for cervical incompetence during pregnancy include:

  • Per speculum examination - shows cervical dilatation with herniation of membranes
  • Transvaginal ultrasound - funneling of internal os >1 cm and cervical length <25 mm
Prophylactic cervical cerclage is done between 12-14 weeks of gestation. Rescue or emergency cerclage is done when there is bulging or prolapse of membranes through a dilated cervix.

questions.text: A 24-year-old lady in her third week postpartum complains of pain in her left breast. She also complains of mild fever, headache, and nausea. Examination reveals a tender breast with red, hot, and flushed overlying skin. There is no fluctuant swelling or discharge. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of a lactating mother presenting with breast pain, fever, headache, nausea, and tender breast with red, hot, and flushed overlying skin points towards a diagnosis of acute mastitis.

The most common organism involved in acute mastitis is Staphylococcus aureus. Other organisms involved are Staphylococcus epidermidis, and Streptococci viridans. The source of organisms is the infant’s nose and throat. It usually occurs during the first 2–4 weeks postpartum.

Clinical features:

  • Generalized malaise
  • Headache
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Fever with chills
  • Severe pain and, non-fluctuant swelling.
  • The overlying skin is red, hot, and flushed, and feels tense and tender

Microscopic examination of breast milk shows leucocytes >106/mL and bacterial count >103/mL. It might lead to the formation of a breast abscess.

Management:

  • Breast support and analgesics
  • Breastfeeding is continued. The infected side is emptied manually with each feed.
  • Dicloxacillin is the drug of choice
  • Erythromycin is given to patients who are allergic to penicillin

Other options:

Option A - Breast engorgement occurs due to exaggerated normal venous and lymphatic engorgement of the breasts which precedes lactation. It is characterized by bilateral breast tenderness and swelling typically present 24 to 72 hours post-partum, peaks 3 to 5 days after delivery and resolves spontaneously. Antibiotics are not indicated. Treatment is by cold compresses and analgesics.

Option B - A galactocele is a milk-filled cavity in the breast of a woman who is usually lactating. It can be caused due to lactation problems, prolactin stimulation by drugs, or duct obstruction. It presents as a palpable, round, well-circumscribed, and freely mobile mass with no fever, pain, or inflammation. It is usually subareolar and unilateral.

Option C - Breast abscess is usually suspected when there is no response to treatment for mastitis in 48-72 hours. It is also characterised by brawny oedema over the affected area, fluctuant lump. Management includes sonography-guided needle aspiration under local anaesthesia. Antibiotics and pumping of the affected breast are also done. Incision and drainage of the abscess are done in cases not responding to aspiration.

questions.text: A young male presents with a painless swelling in the right testis, which he noticed two months ago. On examination, the swelling is firm and non-tender, with no transillumination and the contralateral testis appears normal. An ultrasound reveals a hypoechoic mass in the right testis. Further imaging shows enlargement of the para-aortic and pre-aortic lymph nodes. Tumor markers, including AFP, β-hCG, and LDH, are elevated. The physician suspects testicular cancer.  What is the next appropriate step in management?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the raised AFP, β-hCG, and LDH levels are suggestive of testicular cancer and the next best step in management is high inguinal orchidectomy.

Clinical features of testicular carcinoma:

  • Painless testicular lump is the most common presenting feature.
  • Epididymo-orchitis.
  • Severe pain and acute enlargement of the testis because of haemorrhage into the tumour.
  • Intra-abdominal spread may cause abdominal or lumbar pain.
  • Lung metastases are usually silent but they can cause chest pain, dyspnoea and haemoptysis in the later stages of the disease.

Although testicular cancers often spread to the retroperitoneal lymph nodes, including the pre-aortic nodes. A biopsy of the scrotal mass or the lymph nodes is generally not the first step.  

A high inguinal approach is crucial because it allows for removal of the testicle along with the spermatic cord, minimizing the risk of further spread. This is the standard initial management for suspected testicular cancer. After removal of the affected testis, metastatic workup should be done with CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis.

Early-stage tumors don't require additional treatment after orchidectomy, while late-stage tumours are given combination chemotherapy with bleomycin, etoposide, and cis-platinum (BEP chemotherapy). They are highly sensitive to combination chemotherapy with BEP. So chemotherapy is given to high-risk cases and low-risk cases with a good prognosis are managed by surveillance protocols.

Other Options:

Option A: Lymph node biopsies, while sometimes necessary, are usually performed after a diagnosis of testicular cancer is established to assess the extent of spread.

Option B: Scrotal biopsies for testicular mass risk seeding the scrotal skin with cancer cells, potentially worsening the prognosis.

Option D: Repeating hormone markers while potentially useful for monitoring the disease after a diagnosis is made is not the priority when a suspicious scrotal mass and concerning lymphadenopathy are present.

Related Pearl: WHO 2016 classification of testicular tumors

I. Germ-cell tumors (GCTs) derived from germ-cell neoplasia in situ

    • Embryonal carcinoma

    • Choriocarcinoma
    • Teratoma, post-pubertal type
  • Mixed germ-cell tumors

II. Germ-cell tumors unrelated to germ-cell neoplasia in situ

  • Spermatocytic tumour
  • Teratoma, prepubertal type
  • Yolk sac tumor, prepubertal type
  • Mixed

III. Sex cord stromal tumors

  • Leydig cell tumor
  • Sertoli cell tumor
  • Granulosa cell tumor
  • Fibroma–thecoma

IV. Tumor containing both germ-cell and sex cord-stromal elements

V. Hematolymphoid tumors

questions.text: Which among the following is the treatment of choice when micro invasion is suspected in cervical neoplasia?
questions.solution:
Conization is the preferred treatment modality when microinvasion is suspected in a patient.

Cone biopsy involves a wide cone excision that includes the entire outer margin of the lesion and the entire endocervical lining, by using the cold-knife technique under general anesthesia. Disadvantages include bleeding, infection, cervical stenosis, and cervical incompetence

Hysterectomy is done when microinvasion is confirmed.

  • Indications of conization
    • Endocervical dysplasia
    • The transformation zone is not completely visualized
    • When there is discrepancy of findings between cytolology, colposcopy & biopsy
    • Microinvasion is suspected
  • Indications of hysterectomy
    • Older & parous women
    • Uterus is suspected with fibroid, DUB, prolapsed
    • Microinvasion exists
    • Recurrence or persistent lesion
    • In – situ adenocarcinoma cervix

Related Pearl: Grades of cervical dysplasia

Severe dysplasia CIN III Dysplastic cells in >2/3 of cervix HSIL Colposcopic directed biopsy + Endocervical curettage

questions.text: A patient with marfanoid habitus, hyperparathyroidism, and neuromas of the tongue presents with a cervical mass.  The most likely cause of the cervical mass is_______.
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is medullary carcinoma of the thyroid which occurs in the setting of MEN 2B.

Medullary carcinoma is seen in both in MEN 2A and 2B. The RET gene is abnormally activated. In Hirschsprung disease, it is deactivated.

MEN 2B: It is characterized by multiple mucosal neuromas, a marfanoid appearance, medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, gastrointestinal ganglioneuromatosis, and thickened corneal nerves. This rare syndrome is inherited in an autosomal-dominant pattern.

Medullary carcinomas arising in the context of MEN-2B are generally more aggressive and metastasize more frequently.

MEN syndromes:

  • The MEN syndromes are a group of inherited diseases, resulting in proliferative lesions (hyperplasia, adenomas, and carcinomas) of multiple endocrine organs.
  • Tumors occur at a younger age than sporadic tumors.
  • Tumors arise in multiple endocrine organs, either synchronously (at the same time) or metachronously (at different times).
MEN1 MEN 2 (previously MEN2A) MEN 3 (previously MEN 2B) MEN 4
Wermer's Syndrome Sipple's Syndrome Mucosal neuromata with endocrine tumors due to mutation in CDKN1B.
  • Parathyroid tumors
  • Pituitary tumors
  • Pancreas tumors
  • Parathyroid tumors
  • Medullary thyroid Carcinoma (MTC)
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC)
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Ganglioneuromatosis

Similar to MEN 1 plus

  • Reproductive organ tumors (e.g. testicular tumors, neuroendocrine cervical carcinoma)
  • Adrenal + Renal tumors

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

Known as Sipple’s syndrome

Associated conditions :

  • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
  • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
  • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

Known commonly as MEN 3

Chromosome 10/ RET gene

questions.text: A middle-aged woman who presented with features of tremors, palpitations, weight loss, and menstrual irregularities is diagnosed with Grave's disease. Which of the following statements is true with respect to the report of the thyroid function test in Graves' disease?

choices.text: Radioactive Iodine Uptake (RAIU) at 24 hours below normal

questions.solution:
In Graves' disease, the level of serum TSH is low, unbound T4 is high and serum T3 is high. 

Graves disease is caused by autoantibodies that bind to the thyrotropin receptor (TSHR-Ab), stimulating the growth of the thyroid and overproduction of thyroid hormone(T4 and T3). These hormones then cause negative feedback to the anterior pituitary and thus, decrease TSH levels.

And in patients with thyrotoxicosis including Graves', the RAIU (radioactive iodine uptake) at 24 hours is characteristically above normal.

The evaluation of thyrotoxicosis is given in the flowchart below:

Related Pearl: Radioactive iodine uptake scan

Toxic MNG Thyrotoxicosis factitia
Toxic adenoma Viral
TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma Metastatic follicular thyroid carcinoma
HCG induced thyrotoxicosis Radiation thyroiditis, Struma ovarii

questions.text: Which of the following increases during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Among the following, fibrinogen increases during pregnancy.

Pregnancy is a hypercoagulable state. 

Hematological changes in pregnancy include:

  • All clotting factors are increased (except factor 11,13) and fibrinogen levels are also increased.
  • The viscosity of blood doesn’t increase since plasma volume increases more in comparison to red cell volume, it merely decreases whole blood viscosity.
  • Clotting time is unaffected.
  • The most common cause of decreased platelet count in pregnancy is benign gestational thrombocytopenia (may be due to hemodilution and increased platelet consumption and women are asymptomatic).
  • Fibrinolytic activity remains depressed till about 15 minutess after pregnancy

questions.text: Identify the given condition:
questions.solution:
The given image is of a port wine stain.

Port wine stains are congenital lesions that may occur anywhere in the body. Visually they appear as partially or completely blanchable, pink to red or reddish brown patches. It is a low-flow vascular malformation.

Commonly they occur as isolated skin lesions but in rare cases, they are part of certain complex syndromes.

This lesion is associated with syndromes such as Sturge-Weber syndrome and occult spinal dysraphism. Port-wine stain occurring in the distribution of the trigeminal nerve is associated with Sturge-Weber syndrome.

Features of port wine stain:

  • It does not fade with time
  • Special form of nevus flammeus
  • Tends to grow during childhood
  • Thicken the skin surface

Sturge-Weber syndrome (SWS) is a severe neurocutaneous disorder. Patients have a capillary malformation on the face and brain (leptomeninges) and abnormal eye blood vessels leading to glaucoma. The capillary malformation or port wine stain appears as a homogenous, pink, red, or purple macule, present at birth. Most children with intracranial vascular anomalies present with seizures before the age of two. Patients also may have hemiparesis, stroke-like episodes, headaches, and developmental delay.

Treatment of the cutaneous vascular lesion can be done by a pulsed-dye laser. Seizures and glaucoma should also be treated.

The image below shows prominent subcortical white matter calcification seen in this disease:

Other Options:

Option A: Lisch nodules are small well-defined nodules that are seen in neurofibromatosis. They are present bilaterally and appear as clear, yellow, or brown elevations above the iris surface as shown in the image below.

Option C: Infantile hemangioma is a common benign vascular tumour in childhood. It presents anywhere on the body and is usually not present at birth. They appear red or maroon if superficial, and bluish if deep. They regress by 4 years of age usually. It is shown in the image below. 

Option D: Café-au-lait macules are flat, pigmented skin patches with a light brown colour, resembling coffee with milk. They can be a normal variation or associated with conditions like neurofibromatosis type 1.

The image below shows café-au-lait macules.

questions.text: A patient presented with a prolonged fever for 2 weeks and new-onset seizures. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) obtained on admission showed a 1.5 cm vegetation on the tricuspid valve. Multiple painless skin lesions are present on the hands as shown in the image below. What are these lesions called?
questions.solution:
The skin lesions shown in the image are Janeway lesions. They are non-tender, erythematous or hemorrhagic macular or nodular lesions, which are present on the palms or soles.

Patients with infective endocarditis can have cardiac or non-cardiac manifestations.

Cardiac manifestations of IE:

  • Presence of new regurgitant murmurs
  • Congestive heart failure due to valve dysfunction
  • Perivalvular abscesses and intracardiac fistulae- This is caused due to the extension of infection beyond the valves and into the adjacent myocardial tissue
  • Conduction system defects- due to the damage of the interventricular septum by the abscess.
  • Embolization of coronary arteries

Noncardiac manifestations of IE are:

  • Arterial emboli- causing pain of ischemia of the organs
  • Osler's nodes-are painful, red, nodular lesions usually located in the pads of the fingers and toes
  • Roth's spots- retinal hemorrhages with a pale center
  • Janeway lesions- In contrast to Osler's nodes, these are faint, red, painless macules on palms and soles. They occur as a result of septic embolization and are commonly associated with staphylococcal IE.
  • Glomerulonephritis
  • Positivity for rheumatoid factor
  • Petechiae on oral and conjunctival mucosa
  • Splinter subungual haemorrhages-painless, dark red lines in the nailbed.
  • Mycotic aneurysms

Another skin finding that can be found in patients with infective endocarditis is Osler's node. In contrast to Janeway lesions, these are small, tender, red papules which are present on the distal finger and toe pads.

The image below depicts Roth's spots which are exudative lesions in the retina. This is an immunological phenomenon.

questions.text: During an intra-oral procedure, the resident uses the given suture material to place sutures on the soft palate. What is this suture material called?
questions.solution:
The suture material shown in the image is plain catgut. It is a yellowish absorbable suture material. 

Chromic catgut is brownish in colour.

Vicryl is a violet-coloured absorbable suture material.

Silk is a black-coloured, multifilament, natural, braided, and non-absorbable suture material. It is derived from the cocoon of the silkworm larva.

Prolene is a blue coloured, monofilament, non-absorbable suture.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman noticed a new mole of 0.4 mm on her forearm. On close examination, it is observed that one-half of the mole is larger and has a different colour compared to the other half. The edges of the mole are irregular and appear jagged. What characteristic in the ABCDE of melanoma is not present in this scenario?
questions.solution:
This patient's mole does not have the D: Diameter characteristic in the ABCDE of melanoma. 

The ABCDE of Melanoma consists of the rules for the examination of a nevus to assess its malignant potential. The D in ABCDE stands for diameter >6 mm. This patient's mole is 0.4 mm in size which is smaller in size in terms of the ABCDE characteristic of melanoma. 

Melanoma:

The ABCDE of Melanoma consists of the rules for the examination of a nevus to assess its malignant potential:

A: Asymmetry-Melanoma lesions are irregular, or not symmetrical, in shape.

B: Border irregular- Melanoma lesions usually have irregular borders that are ill-defined.

C: Color variegation- The presence of multiple colours (blue, black, brown, tan, etc.) or the uneven distribution of colour.

D: Diameter >6 mm-Melanoma lesions are often greater than 6 millimetres in diameter (approximately the size of a pencil eraser).

E: Evolution- There is a change in the size, shape, symptoms (such as itching or tenderness), surface (especially bleeding), or colour of a mole.

The image below shows a case of malignant melanoma.

questions.text:
A pregnant woman presented with complaints of passing grape-like vesicles vaginally. She also had frequent episodes of vomiting. A USG scan was done and is shown below. Which of the following is not recommended post-evacuation for this condition?

hCG - Human Chorionic Gonadotropin

choices.text: Administer anti-D if mother is Rh-ve
Allow pregnancy after 6 months of monitoring, if HCG titres are negative
Check hCG levels within 48 hours of evacuation
Can insert intrauterine devices for contraception

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of molar pregnancy and intrauterine devices are not recommended during the period of surveillance, post evacuation.

Molar pregnancy may present with bleeding per vaginum or an acute discharge of vesicular mass per vaginum. On examination, the uterine size is more than the corresponding period of amenorrhea. It shows a characteristic snowstorm appearance on USG.  

Suction and evacuation is the treatment of choice. Here post evacuation, Intrauterine devices are not recommended during the period of surveillance. This is because there is increased risk of perforation during this period if an invasive mole is present.

Post-evacuation recommendations:

  • Anti-D immune globulin if Rh D-negative
  • Initiate effective contraception-combination hormonal contraception, injectable depot medroxyprogesterone acetate, or progestin implant.
  • Review pathology report
  • Serum hCG levels: within 48 h of evacuation→ weekly until undetectable→ then monthly for 6 months.

Pregnancy is allowed after 6 months following a negative hCG titer. However, it is advised to avoid pregnancy for 1 year, preferably 2 years, as a fresh pregnancy will interfere with the hCG titres.

questions.text: All of the following are true about Meckel’s diverticulum except_____.

choices.text: Located 60 cm proximal to ileocecal valve

questions.solution:
All of the following are true about Meckel’s diverticulum except that it arises at the mesenteric border. Meckel’s diverticula arise from the antimesenteric border.

Meckel’s Diverticulum:

  • Meckel’s diverticulum is caused by a failure of normal regression of the vitelline duct that develops during weeks 5 to 7 of gestation.
  • The most commonly encountered congenital anomaly of the small intestine.
  • Located on the antimesenteric border of the ileum
  • The rule of 2s (Mnemonic for Meckel’s diverticulum) :
    • 2 types of heterotopic mucosa (gastric & pancreatic)
    • 2% incidence
    • located within 2 feet of the ileocecal valve-45 to 60 cm proximal to the ileocecal valve
    • approximately 2 inches in length
    • Usually symptomatic by 2 years of age
  • Most common presentation is painless, massive, lower GI bleed in children younger than 5 years.
  • A Meckel's can be the lead point for ileoileal or ileocolic intussusception.
  • The bleeding Meckel's diverticulum may be confirmed by a 99 mTc-pertechnetate isotope scan to detect gastric mucosa.
  • Surgical treatment is the definitive therapy for Meckel’s diverticulum. A simple V-shaped diverticulectomy with transverse closure of the ileum is the ideal surgical approach.

questions.text: What ratio of chest compressions to rescue breaths is given during CPR in an adult if 2 rescuers are present?
questions.solution:
During cardiopulmonary resuscitation of adults, the ratio of chest compression to rescue breaths is 30:2 irrespective of the number of rescuers.

In infants and children, the ratio is 30:2 for a single rescuer and 15:2 if 2 or more rescuers are present.

Related Pearl: High quality CPR for adults

  • Push hard: 5-6cm depth
  • Push fast: 100-120/min frequency
  • Allow for complete chest recoil
  • Minimize interruptions in compressions <10 seconds
  • Avoid excessive ventilation
  • Rotate compressor every 2 min or earlier if fatigued
  • If no advanced airway, 30:2 compression-ventilation ratio

Attempt to improve CPR quality if :

  • Quantitative waveform capnography - PETCO2 <10mmHg, 
  • Intra-arterial pressure - If relaxation phase (diastolic) pressure <20mmHg

Related Pearl: Basic Life Support (BLS) Algorithm

Related Pearl: Adult cardiac arrest algorithm (Updated as per 2020 guidelines)

questions.text: A diagnosis of gouty arthritis is made after aspiration of the synovial fluid and polarised light microscopy shows negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals.  These crystals are
questions.solution:
Negatively birefringent, needle-shaped crystals seen on polarised light microscopy in gouty arthritis is due to the deposition of monosodium urate crystals.

Other options:

Option A- Calcium apatite crystals can accumulate in areas of tissue damage, hypercalcemic, or hyperparathyroid states.

Option C- Calcium pyrophosphate crystals are rhomboid-shaped and are seen in pseudogout.

Option D- Calcium Oxalate crystals are seen in chronic renal failure.

Monosodium urate crystals in gout-

Calcium pyrophosphate crystals seen in pseudogout-

questions.text: A 35-year-old female is recently diagnosed with dermatomyositis.  Positive titers of which of the following antibodies are associated with mechanic's hand?
questions.solution:
Positive titers of Anti-Jo-1 (antisynthetase antibodies) are associated with interstitial lung disease, arthritis, and mechanic's hands.

Other autoantibodies seen in dermatomyositis are-

  • Anti-Mi-2: Highly specific to dermatomyositis
  • Anti-SRP (anti-signal recognition protein): Associated with severe myositis 
  • Anti–PM-Scl: Associated with overlapping myositis and scleroderma
  • Anti-p155/140 or antitranscription intermediary factor (TIF)-1γ: Seen in cancer associated myositis
  • Anti-MDA5 (anti-CADM 140): Associated with rapidly progressive lung disease and cutaneous ulcer.

questions.text: Tests for ovarian reserve were done in an infertile female who has been planned for ovulation induction. Which of the following test is the best indicator for ovarian reserve?
questions.solution:
FSH is the best indicator of ovarian reserve among the given options.

Ovarian reserve means the capacity of the ovary to produce eggs.

High FSH means the ovarian reserve is getting depleted and fewer oocytes are remaining in the ovary (FSH is highest in postmenopausal women). FSH levels are higher than normal in women with reduced ovarian reserve and ovarian hypofunction. FSH levels are measured in the early follicular phase (Day 2 or 3 of the menstrual cycle)

Anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) is a better marker than FSH for ovarian reserve and has the advantage that its levels can be estimated at any time of the cycle, unlike FSH. AMH is produced by the Granulosa cells in ovarian follicles (In males, it is produced by the Sertoli cells). AMH in females is always absent during embryogenesis.

LH/FSH ratio may be useful in certain clinical scenarios, such as diagnosing certain disorders or conditions affecting the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis. However, it is not typically used as a primary marker for assessing ovarian reserve.

Studies show that AMH levels decrease under the current use of oral contraceptives and current tobacco smoking.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl presents with precocious puberty, bony lesions, and hyperpigmented skin lesions, as shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Precocious puberty, bony lesions (polyostotic fibrous dysplasia), and cafe au lait spots, as shown in the picture, are features of McCune–Albright syndrome.

McCune–Albright syndrome is a classical cause of peripheral precocious puberty caused by a mutation of the GNAS1 gene. It affects the bones, skin, and several endocrine tissues.

Cardinal features:

  • Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia
  • Cafe au lait macules
  • Endocrine abnormalities: hyperthyroidism, acromegaly, adrenal adenomas, and autonomous ovarian hyperfunction, leading to precocious puberty
  • Predominantly affects girls

questions.text:
A teenage girl presented with irregular menstrual cycles and increased facial hair. On USG, her ovaries were enlarged. Which of the following are used in the first line treatment?
  1. Laparoscopic ovarian drilling
  2. Anti-androgens
  3. Lifestyle modifications
  4. Combined oral contraceptive pills
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of polycystic ovarian syndrome and anti-androgens, lifestyle modifications, and combined oral contraceptives (2, 3, and 4) represent the first-line treatment modalities for this condition. Laparoscopic drilling is a surgical management procedure done when medical therapy fails. 

This patient's irregular menstrual cycles, increased facial hair (signifying clinical hyperandrogenism), and increased ovarian volume are suggestive of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS).

PCOS is an endocrinopathy seen in women of reproductive age, affecting multiple systems. The Rotterdam criteria is used to diagnose PCOS. The presence of any two of the three components of this criteria establishes the diagnosis of PCOS.

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism (hirsutism, acne)
  • Menstrual abnormalities (Oligo/amenorrhoea), anovulation, infertility
  • Polycystic ovaries on ultrasound.

Sonographic criteria for polycystic ovaries include ≥ 12 small cysts or an increased ovarian volume (> 10 mL) or both. 

Ultrasound image given below shows an enlarged ovary seen in PCOS with multiple follicles in the periphery.

Management:

  • Weight reduction alone is beneficial in mild hirsutism and lifestyle changes (like smoking cessation) are advised in the management of PCOS.
  • Oral contraceptive pills (OCP), preferably fourth-generation pills with 30 mcg E2 and 2-3 mg drospirenone are used to treat menstrual abnormalities. It also reduces acne and further hirsutism.
  • Anti-androgens are useful in treating hirsutism. OCP with cyproterone acetate is prescribed for PCOS patients with hirsutism. 
  • Patients with PCOD are more prone to developing insulin resistance which can be controlled with metformin. Acarbose can be used if metformin is contraindicated
  • Patients presenting with infertility are treated by inducing ovulation using clomiphene as a first-line drug, along with dexamethasone and letrozole.

Surgical options include laparoscopic ovarian drilling or puncture of not more than four cysts in each ovary. This is done either by laser or by unipolar electrocautery. It restores the endocrine levels and improves fertility.

Surgery is indicated only if,

  • Medical therapy fails
  • Hyperstimulation occurs
  • Infertile women
  • Previous pregnancy losses

 

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 - 70 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

Related Pearl: Management of PCOD

Complaint Management  
Irregular periods OCPs
Obesity Lifestyle modification
Insulin resistance Metformin
Hirsutism /acne OCPs with cyproterone acetate
Infertility Clomiphene

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a known history of DM and HTN on regular medications presents with a history of progressively worsening dyspnoea on exertion. On examination, there is elevated JVP, positive hepatojugular reflux, crackles at the lung bases, hepatomegaly, ascites, and pedal oedema​. What is your provisional diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of heart failure.

Heart failure is a complex clinical syndrome that occurs because the ventricle is unable to fill with or eject blood. The etiology of heart failure includes:

  • Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Coronary artery disease
  • Cardiomyopathies
  • Chronic kidney disease
  • High output states, such as beriberi, thyrotoxicosis, severe anemia

Signs and symptoms of heart failure are:

Right heart failure Left heart failure
Due to congestion in the systemic circulation Due to congestion in the lungs. 

Symptoms and signs:

  • Raised JVP
  • Congestive hepatomegaly
  • Positive hepatojugular reflux
  • Ascites
  • Bilateral pitting edema 
  • Weight gain- due to edema
  • Fatigue- due to ↓pumping of blood to lungs leading to ↓oxygenation of the blood

Symptoms and signs: 

  • Dyspnea on exertion
  • Orthopnea
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea (characteristic of LVF)
  • Pulmonary rales 
  • Increased PCWP
  • Fatigue- due to ↓cardiac output

questions.text: A patient presents with a hernia medial to the inferior epigastric artery. What is the most likely diagnosis and appropriate management for the same?

choices.text: Direct hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair
Indirect hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a hernia medial to the inferior epigastric artery is suggestive of a direct hernia, which is managed surgically by Lichtenstein mesh repair.

The contents of a direct hernia protrude outward, forward, and medially to the inferior epigastric artery and the superficial inguinal ring. It protrudes through the Hesselbach triangle which is a zone of weakness for a direct hernia. Whereas, the contents of an indirect hernia protrude laterally to the inferior epigastric artery. The sac of an indirect inguinal hernia passes from the deep inguinal ring obliquely towards the superficial inguinal ring and then reaches the scrotum.

A Lichtenstein mesh repair is currently one of the most frequently used methods for treating an inguinal hernia. It is done for reconstruction of the inguinal floor in adults. It is an anterior tension-free mesh repair that reduces the chances of recurrence of a hernia. A piece of prosthetic nonabsorbable mesh is used to bridge the defect in this repair.

Other surgical methods used for the repair of a hernia are:

  • Bassini repair - It is done for the reconstruction of the inguinal floor in adults. In this method, a mesh is not used. It is associated with a high recurrence and is not used frequently now. It is used only in cases of hernial strangulation and peritonitis where the use of a mesh is not preferred. It is performed by suturing the transversus abdominis and internal oblique musculoaponeurotic arches/conjoined tendon to the inguinal ligament. 
  • Shouldice repair - It is a multilayered repair, where the posterior wall of the inguinal canal is strengthened by continuous sutures. It involves double-breasting of the transversalis fascia. It is associated with a very low recurrence rate.
  • Gilbert repair (plug and patch repair) - It is an extension of Lichtenstein’s original mesh repair and has now become the most commonly performed primary anterior inguinal hernia repair. In this technique, a cone-shaped plug of polypropylene mesh is used. It is deployed like an upside-down umbrella when inserted into the internal inguinal ring to occlude the hernia
  • Stoppa-Rives repair - It is used for the repair of large, recurrent, or bilateral hernias. In this method, a sub-umbilical midline incision is given to place a large mesh into the preperitoneal space.
  • Herniotomy - It is used to treat inguinal hernia in a child which occurs due to the presence of a patent processus vaginalis. Therefore in herniotomy, the repair of the inguinal ring is not done

Related Pearl: Boundaries of Hesselbach’s triangle

  • Lateral - inferior epigastric artery
  • Medial - lateral border of rectus abdominis
  • Inferior - inguinal ligament

Direct inguinal hernia emerges through Hesselbach’s triangle (Hence situated medial to inferior epigastric artery)

Indirect inguinal hernia enters deep inguinal ring (Hence it is lateral to inferior epigastric artery)

questions.text: A 6-year-old child was brought to the outpatient department with a history of fever and upper respiratory tract infection for the past few days. On examination, the following is observed. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The child in the image presented with the classical slapped cheek appearance of erythema infectiosum caused by parvovirus B19. It is also called the fifth disease.

This disease usually presents as a respiratory infection with an erythematous maculopapular rash and arthralgia. This erythematous appearance of the cheeks is called slapped cheek appearance. Children between the age of 5-15 years of age are commonly affected by this disease.

Related Pearl: Skin rashes: 1st to 6th diseases
