questions.text: A mother started to feel sad and tearful over the first two weeks following childbirth. She felt overwhelmed by the responsibilities of nursing her baby and changing diapers and waking up in the middle of the night. She felt that she was a failure as a mother. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of postpartum blues. 

It is characterized by a labile mood, sadness, and subjective confusion. It is thought to be due to changes in hormone levels, the stress of childbirth, and anxiety about the responsibilities of motherhood. This usually resolves spontaneously. 

If symptoms last longer than 2 weeks, an evaluation for postpartum depression is needed.

Disorders and features Incidence and timeline Harmful thoughts Treatment

Postpartum blues:

Depressed affect, tearfulness and fatigue

30-75%

Starts 2-3 days after delivery. Resolves within 10 days.

 No thoughts of harming the baby Support and follow up

Postpartum depression:

Depressed affect, anxiety and poor concentration

10-15%

Starts within 12 weeks from delivery and persists for ≥ 2 weeks. 

 Thoughts of harming the baby often present CBT and SSRIs 

Postpartum psychosis:

Mood-congruent delusions, hallucinations

 0.1-0.2% Thoughts of harming the baby or self Hospitalization, atypical antipsychotics and ECT for refractory cases

questions.text: Identify the structure marked A:
questions.solution:
The structure marked is primary oocyte.

  • Primary oocyte are the germ cells in the medullary region of the ovary which enlarge at the beginning of the growth phase until puberty.

  • During this cell growth period, many oocytes undergo degeneration, both before and after birth. A single layer of flattened follicular cells that were derived originally from the germinal epithelium soon surrounds the primary oocytes. These structures are now called primordial follicles and are seen first in the medulla and later in the cortex.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect regarding pheochromocytoma?

choices.text: Surgical  excision is the definitive  treatment
Propranolol is given initially to manage hypertension
Can present as hypertension alone,  sometimes with vomiting and  pain abdomen

questions.solution:
Alpha-blockers like phenoxybenzamine are given initially to manage hypertension in pheochromocytoma. Beta-blockers such as propranolol are given only after adequate alpha blockade is achieved.

Pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine secreting tumor. High levels of circulating catecholamines stimulate the alpha receptors on the blood vessels and cause vasoconstriction, resulting in hypertension. If β-blockers are given initially, it will lead to unopposed α-stimulant action of catecholamines leading to hypertensive crisis. This is the rationale behind prescribing alpha-blockers initially and then followed by β-blockers in pheochromocytoma.

 

Pheochromocytoma:

Pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine secreting tumor derived from the chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla.

It can be sporadical or hereditary. Hereditary pheochromocytoma occurs in association with syndromes such as MEN 2 (Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2), familial paraganglioma syndrome, Von Hippel Lindau (VHL) syndrome, and neurofibromatosis (NF) type 1.

Clinical features:

It most commonly presents as a classic triad of intermittent headache, palpitation, and profuse sweating along with hypertension. The patient can also present with anxiety, panic attacks, nausea, abdominal pain, weight loss, and weakness.

Symptoms may be precipitated by surgery, pregnancy, position changes, exercise, and medications such as metoclopramide and tricyclic antidepressants.

Investigations:

  1. Biochemical screening test - measurement of urinary and plasma levels of catecholamines and metanephrines. 
  2. MRI is the investigation of choice for localizing the tumor. It is preferred over a CT scan as the contrast used in CT scans can precipitate paroxysms.
  3. Other imaging modalities like MIBG scintigraphy, DOPA- or FDG- PET scan are used in identifying the primary tumor as well as the extra-adrenal tumors and metastases.

Treatment:

Surgical resection of the tumor is the definitive treatment for pheochromocytoma.

Preoperatively, hypertension is managed initially with alpha-blockers followed by beta-blockers.

Postoperatively, lifelong yearly follow-up should be done.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the clinic with complaints of recurrent palpitation and lightheadedness. An ECG was taken and is shown below. What is the best step in management?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows the presence of delta waves (preexcitation wave), wide QRS, and short PR interval which are classically seen in WPW syndrome. In this patient, catheter ablation is the best for long-term management. 

Patients with preexcitation who have symptoms of arrhythmia are at risk for developing AF and sudden death if they have an accessory pathway that allows rapid antegrade conduction (preexcitation & tachyarrhythmias are features of WPW syndrome due to the abnormal accessory pathway).

Complications of catheter ablation are rare but include AV block, cardiac tamponade, thromboembolic events, and hematoma at the access site.

Related Pearl: Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome

Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome (WPW) is characterized by an abnormal accessory pathway in the heart leading to arrhythmias.

Pathology- Born with an accessory pathway, the bundle of Kent which connects the atria and ventricle. The electrical impulses from the SA node reach the ventricles earlier via the accessory pathway as there is no AV nodal delay in this pathway. This leads to the preexcitation of the ventricle and initiation of ventricular contraction. This ventricular contraction is prolonged when the impulse via the AV nodal pathway reaches the ventricles.

Most common location of the accessory pathway- between the left atrium and free wall of the left ventricle

ECG changes:

Shortened PR interval- because of the early initiation of ventricular depolarization

Prolonged QRS duration- because of the AV nodal impulse reaching the ventricles after the aberrant impulse.

Delta waves- slurred upstroke of QRS complex

The given ECG shows delta waves marked with red arrows:

Treatment:

  • Catheter ablation is the treatment of choice.
  • Anti-arrhythmic drugs like procainamide, amiodarone, quinidine, propafenone, dofetilide are used in slowing conduction in the accessory pathway (prolong refractory period).
  • IV procainamide is the drug of choice in a hemodynamically stable WPW presenting with atrial fibrillation.
  • DC cardioversion is done in hemodynamically unstable patients.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was brought to the paediatrician with complaints of bilateral knee pain. His bone mineral density is normal.  The X-ray image of the joints is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and the X-ray showing Pelkan spurs, Trummerfeld zone, and Frenkel's line are suggestive of scurvy.

Radiological findings in scurvy:

  • Frenkel's line - Zone of provisional calcification at the growing metaphysis is seen as a dense, white line called the Frankel's line.
  • Pelkan spurs - These are metaphyseal spurs formed due to fractures manifesting at the cortical margins. 
  • Wimberger’s ring sign - The sclerotic rim around the epiphysis forms this appearance.
  • Trummerfeld zone. - Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line.

Scurvy results from the deficiency of vitamin C, which is required for the hydroxylation of lysine and proline in procollagen. There is the defective formation of connective tissue and collagen in the skin, bone, cartilage, dentine, and blood vessels which leads to their fragility.

Early manifestations include irritability, loss of appetite, musculoskeletal pain, and tenderness in the legs. Later on, the child can have swelling of the knees, ankles, and pseudo paralysis. Hemorrhagic manifestations of scurvy include petechiae, purpura, ecchymoses at pressure points, epistaxis, gum bleeding, and characteristic perifollicular haemorrhages.

Other manifestations are poor wound and fracture healing, hyperkeratosis of hair follicles, arthralgia, and muscle weakness. It also results in defective osteoid formation. Costo-chondral separation leads to the formation of tender nodules, which are sharply angulated also known as the scorbutic rosary.

Other options:

Option C: Metaphyseal dysplasia: It is also known as Pyle's disease. There is a failure of remodelling the metaphysis. Erlenmeyer flask deformities of the distal femur and proximal tibia are seen in this condition. The patient can also develop genu valgum.

Option D: Pycnodysostosis: It is an autosomal recessive condition due to a mutation in the cathepsin K (CTSK) gene. It causes osteosclerosis and the affected individual has distinctive facial features and skeletal malformations. The patient has short stature and is prone to recurrent fractures due to their fragile bones. 

Related Pearl: Radiological features of scurvy

Radiological features of scurvy:

  • Generalised osteopenia
  • Pencil-point cortex: Cortical thinning
  • Periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage
  • Scorbutic rosary: Expansion of the costochondral junctions
  • Hemarthrosis
  • Wimberger ring: Circular, opaque radiological shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification, which may result from bleeding
  • Frenkel line: Dense zone of provisional calcification 
  • Trummerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  • Pelken spur: Metaphyseal spurs which result in cupping of the metaphysis

Related Pearl: Radiological features of rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

The below image shows bowing of legs in rickets.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with painless hematuria. He is diagnosed with non-invasive bladder cancer. After resection, he was categorised into a high-risk category. What is the next best step in the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
The next step in this patient with a high-risk category of non-muscle-invasive bladder cancer(NMIBC) is intravesical administration of BCG.

Clinical features of bladder carcinoma include:

  • Painless gross haematuria - Most common symptom and is indicative of a bladder carcinoma until proven otherwise
  • Urinary retention
  • Constant pelvic pain
  • Increased urinary frequency
  • Discomfort while urinating
  • If there is nerve involvement, pain is referred to the suprapubic region, groins, perineum, and thighs.

 Management of bladder cancer:

Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer: The aim of managing patients with NMIBC is to reduce the risk of tumour recurrence and progression to muscle-invasive bladder cancer(MIBC). The initial management consists of transurethral resection of bladder tumours(TURBT). Following this patients are stratified according to the risk of recurrence and progression.

  • Highest risk tumours: Radical cystectomy or intravesical bacillus Calmette–Guérin (BCG)
  • Intermediate-risk tumours: a 6-week course of intravesical mitomycin C.
  • Low-risk tumours regular cystoscopic surveillance alone.

Muscle invasive bladder cancer:

  • Radical cystectomy along with urinary diversion procedure and lymph node dissection +/- neoadjuvant chemotherapy.
  • Systemic chemotherapy with a combination of drugs – cisplatin, methotrexate, doxorubicin, and vinblastine (M-VAC) or cisplatin along with gemcitabine is given before radical cystectomy(neoadjuvant).
  • Radical beam external radiotherapy for very elderly or unfit patients who are unsuitable for radical cystectomy.

The most important prognostic factor in bladder carcinoma is the depth of invasion.

questions.text: Transplant of an organ/tissue from mother to child is an example of:
questions.solution:
Transplant of an organ/tissue from a mother to a child is an example of an allograft.

An allograft is a transplant of cells/tissues/organs from a genetically non-identical donor of the same species.

Isograft  is the transfer of cells/tissues/organs are transplanted from a donor to a genetically identical recipient. (monozygotic twins)

Xenograft is tissue transfer from a donor of one species to a recipient of another species. It is also known as heterograft

Autograft is the transfer of tissue from one location to another location on the same patient.

questions.text: A 75-year-old patient comes with a complaint of headache, visual disturbances and back pain. His physical examination was normal except for pallor and enlarged prostate. X-ray of the back showed diffuse osteolytic lesions. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is with osteolytic lesions and pallor most likely has multiple myeloma.

Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell dyscrasia in which there is an unregulated proliferation of plasma cells. The proliferating cells stimulate osteoclastic activity and suppress osteoblastic activity, leading to the formation of multiple lytic bone lesions. These lesions can be seen on radiographs as 'punched out' lesions.  In some severe cases, patients may present with pathological fractures.

Other features of multiple myeloma:

  • Acute renal failure in a dehydrated state
  • Normocytic normochromic anaemia 
  • Hyperviscosity syndromes cause headache, exacerbation, or precipitation of heart failure, visual disturbances, ataxia, and vertigo
  • Bony damage leading to cord compression
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome
  • Sensory more than motor neuropathy associated with IgM directed against myelin-associated globulin

Carcinoma of the prostate is the most common malignant tumour in men over the age of 65 years. Hematogenous spread occurs chiefly through the bones to the axial skeleton and rarely to the viscera. The bony metastasis is blastic in origin and involves the lumbar spine, proximal femur, pelvis, thoracic spine, and ribs in decreasing order of frequency. 

Osteosarcoma is predominantly osteoblastic. This patient could have benign prostatic hyperplasia as it is very common in old age. But it is not a malignant condition and does not cause metastasis.

Related Pearl: Types of metastasis(osteoblastic or osteolytic) and their primary:

Predominantly osteoblastic:

  • Prostate cancer
  • Osteosarcoma 
  • Medullary carcinoma thyroid

Mixed osteoblastic and osteolytic:

  • Breast cancer(preponderance toward osteolytic)
  • Lymphoma
  • Urothelial carcinoma 
  • Lung cancer

Predominantly osteolytic:

  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • Multiple myeloma 
  • Thyroid carcinoma(except medullary carcinoma thyroid)
  • Gastrointestinal tract carcinoma
  • Malignant melanoma

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient with a history of chronic smoking presented with Intermittent calf pain. Angiography shows an inverted tree-like appearance of arteries of both lower limbs. All of the following clinical features can be seen in this patient except:
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of the given scenario is thromboangiitis obliterans / Buerger disease. Acrocyanosis has no association with TAO.

Acrocyanosis is persistent, painless cyanosis seen in fingers and often in legs with paraesthesia and chilblains affecting young females.

Buerger's disease is a progressive nonatherosclerotic segmental inflammatory disease that most often affects small- and medium-sized arteries, veins, and nerves of the lower extremities. It is characterized by occlusive disease of small- and medium-sized arteries, thrombophlebitis of the superficial or deep veins, and Raynaud’s syndrome.

Clinical features:

  • Common in male smokers below 40 years of age group
  • Intermittent claudication in foot and calf progressing to rest pain, ulceration, gangrene.
  • Recurrent migratory superficial thrombophlebitis.
  • Absent/feeble pulses distal to proximal; dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, popliteal, femoral arteries.
  • May present as Raynaud’s phenomenon.
  • Raynaud's phenomenon is episodic vasospasm. It leads to a sequence of clinical features called Raynaud’s syndrome comprising of local syncope, local asphyxia, and local recovery.

Raynaud’s phenomenon

Acrocyanosis

Episodic

Persistent

Painful

Painless

Acute arteriolar spasm

Chronic constriction

Ischaemic changes are common

Ischaemic changes are not seen

Investigations:

  • Arterial doppler and duplex scan (doppler + B-mode U/S).
  • Transfemoral retrograde angiogram through Seldinger technique shows blockage—sites, extent, and severity
    • The corkscrew appearance of the vessel is due to dilatation of vasa vasorum.
    • Inverted tree/spider leg collaterals.
    • Severe vasospasm causing corrugated/rippled artery. 
    • Distal runoff is the amount of dye filling in the main vessel distal to the obstruction through collaterals. If the distal run-off is good then ischemia is compensated. If the distal run-off is poor then ischemia is decompensated.

Treatment:

  • Cessation of smoking is the definitive management. 
  • Drugs to improve circulation include
    • Pentoxifylline
    • Aspirin
    • Clopidogrel
    • Statins 
    • Cilostazol- Phosphodiesterase inhibitor is ideally used to improve circulation in the collaterals formed.
    • Vasodilators and anticoagulants have no role in the treatment.
  • Care of limb with Buerger’s exercise and positioning 
  • Surgical management may include lumbar sympathectomy and amputation according to the presenting features.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented to the clinic with a history suggestive of a transient ischemic attack 5 hours ago. Which of the following can be used to determine the risk for future stroke?
questions.solution:
The risk of stroke following transient ischemic attacks (TIA) is determined by the ABCD2 score.

TIA is a temporary, focal neurological deficit of sudden onset (stroke-like symptoms) lasting for less than 24 hours.

This occurs due to focal ischemia of the brain, retina, or cochlea. There is a high risk of developing an ischemic stroke after a TIA, especially for the first 3 months following a TIA. 

The components of the ABCD2 are shown in the table below

Age ≥60 years 1 point
<60 years 0 points
Blood pressure elevation when first assessed after TIA Systolic ≥ 140 mm Hg or Diastolic ≥90 mm Hg 1 point
Systolic <140 mm Hg and diastolic < 90 mm Hg 0 points
Clinical features Unilateral weakness 2 points
Isolated speech disturbance 1 point
Other  0 points
Duration of TIA symptoms   ≥60 minutes 2 points
10 to 59 minutes 1 point
<10 minutes 0 points
 Diabetes Present 1 point
Absent  0 points

 Interpretation of ABCD2 score:

  • Score 6 to 7: High two-day stroke risk
  • Score 4 to 5: Moderate two-day stroke risk
  • Score 0 to 3: Low two-day stroke risk

Other options:

Options B and C: BISAP (bedside index of severity in a/c pancreatitis) and APACHE II are used for assessing the severity of Acute pancreatitis.

Option D: CHADS2 score determines the risk of stroke in Atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: A school-going girl presents with jaundice and chronic fatigue. Examination revealed splenomegaly and conjunctival pallor. Blood tests show normocytic anemia, large spherical red blood cells without central pallor, and unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Her elder brother also has similar symptoms. Genetic testing shows a mutation in the gene coding for ankyrin. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Normocytic anemia with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, and splenomegaly is suggestive of hemolytic anemia. Ankyrin deficiency as well as family history points to the diagnosis as hereditary spherocytosis.

Hereditary spherocytosis is a type of hereditary hemolytic anemia that is passed down in an autosomal dominant pattern. Mutations of the red blood cell surface proteins spectrin and ankyrin can result in unstable cell membranes, leading to hemolysis.

This disorder can present at a young age with severe jaundice and fatigue. The unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia predisposes the patient to develop gallstones. Hence, childhood gallstones should raise suspicion for this diagnosis.

Laboratory findings include normocytic anemia with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The peripheral smear will show large spherical red blood cells without central pallor. The diagnosis can be confirmed by the acid glycerol lysis test and the eosin-5′-maleimide (EMA)–binding test. 

There is no specific treatment available besides splenectomy. However, due to the possible adverse effects, it is only indicated in severe cases and after the child attains puberty in moderate cases. It should be followed up with the appropriate antibiotic and vaccine prophylaxis.

Other options:

Option (A): Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency is a type of inherited hemolytic anemia. It is associated with exacerbations after consuming anti-malarial drugs and in periods of oxidative stress. It is not associated with ankyrin mutations. It is an X-linked disorder so it is unlikely to be seen in this patient.

Option (B): Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria is a hemolytic disorder that also presents with pancytopenia and a tendency to form venous thrombi. It occurs due to defective GPI anchors on the red blood cell surface which are normally used to anchor CD 59 (cell-protective proteins) to the surface. These patients can present with episodes of dark brown urine in the morning, anemia, pancytopenia, and recurrent abdominal pain due to thrombosis of abdominal veins.

Option (D): Hereditary elliptocytosis is also a type of inherited hemolytic anemia that results from spectrin and similar surface protein mutations. The clinical presentation is very similar to spherocytosis, but the peripheral smear will show elongated elliptical red blood cells instead of spherical ones.

Related Pearl: Classification of Hemolytic Anemias

 

Intracorpuscular Defects

Extracorpuscular Factors

Hereditary

Hemoglobinopathies

Enzymopathies

Membrane-cytoskeletal defects

Familial (atypical) hemolytic uremic syndrome

Acquired

Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH)

Mechanical destruction (microangiopathic)

Toxic agents

Drugs

Infectious

Autoimmune

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman working in a chemical industry is not given protective masks and goggles. The employer is liable under?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the employer is liable under the Factories (Amendment) Act, 1987.

The Factories Act, 1948 has prescribed in detail the precautions to be taken for ensuring the safety of the workers. Including protective devices (like goggles) and precautions against dangerous fumes.

The Factories Act was amended in the year 1987. It stipulates pre-employment examination as a pre-placement procedure, and statutory periodic medical examination for a job in hazardous areas.

Other options:

  • The Maternity Act, 2017: it enhances the duration of paid maternity leave.
  • The Employees State Insurance Act, 1948: It provides for certain cash and medical benefits to industrial employees in case of sickness, maternity, and employment injury.
  • Rajiv Gandhi Shramik Kalyan Yojna, 2005: It provides an unemployment allowance for the employees covered under the ESI Scheme.

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

  • The act defines factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 
  • Age of employment –  prohibition children of < 14 years from working.
  • Adolescents between 15 – 18 years
    • Can be employed  only in certain industries and  work between 6 AM – 7 PM
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours
    • They are allowed to take leave once in every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days
  • Hours of work for adults: maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day, if working overtime then it should be no more than 60 hrs per week
  • Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person
  • Safety and Welfare measures:
    • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
    • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
    • > 250 Workers – Canteen
    • > 50 Workers- Crèche*

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law which has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers- 12 weeks to 26 weeks
  • Working mothers, already with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

 

*for fifty women worker after the 1976 amendment.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with loin pain. Urine examination shows 120rbc/hpf. Urine microscopy revealed dysmorphic RBCs in urine. The site of origin is _______.
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical scenario, the most likely origin is kidney.

Dysmorphic hematuria is typical of glomerulonephritis.

When the source of hematuria is the kidney, RBCs pass through the tubule and hence deformed.

The presence of eumorphic RBCs in urine indicate that the source of bleeding is below the pelvis.

Causes of hematuria

  • Renal 
  • Systemic

Renal causes can be glomerular and non-glomerular

Glomerular Non-glomerular
Dysmorphic RBCs seen (abnormal shape and size) Isomorphic RBCs seen [ normal shape and size]
Rbc casts may be present Rbc casts always absent 
Mcv is small [ <72 fl] Mcv is normal
Protein leakage is more ( >1g/day) Protein leakage is less (<1g/day)
Cause is usually medical Cause is usally surgical

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal?

choices.text: Proctoscopy is the investigation of choice
Most common presentation is ano-rectal pain
Most common type of anal canal carcinoma

questions.solution:
Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the most common anal canal carcinoma. SCC > Basal cell carcinoma >Melanoma

The median age at diagnosis for SCC is 60 years. Patients most commonly present with bleeding per rectum. Commonly metastasizes to the liver and lungs. The most common site of lymph node metastasis is inguinal lymph nodes. 

Risk Factors:

  • Human papillomavirus (HPV) (types 16, 18, 31, 33) infection 
  • Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) or immunosuppression
  • Smoking
  • Anal receptive intercourse
  • Sexual promiscuity
  • Anal intraepithelial neoplasia
  • History of vulvar or cervical cancer

Diagnosis:

  • Proctoscopy with biopsy- investigation of choice 
  • MRI- for local staging 
  • CT scan- to evaluate for distant metastasis

Treatment :

  • Nigro regimen- chemoradiation is the treatment of choice
  • If any residual tumor is left behind after chemoradiation, abdominoperineal resection (APR) is performed

questions.text: Avascular necrosis of the femur head is due to which of the following artery?
questions.solution:
Avascular necrosis of the femoral head is mostly due to the medial circumflex femoral artery.

The blood supply of the femoral head is derived from an arterial ring (trochanteric anastomosis) around the neck of the femur constituted by:

  • Medial and lateral circumflex femoral arteries, branches of profunda femoris artery
  • Superior and inferior gluteal vessels (minor contributions)

In the fetus and early postnatal period, the medial and lateral circumflex femoral arteries contribute equally. Whereas in the later life the supply from the lateral circumflex femoral artery diminishes and it is mainly supplied by two major arteries of the medial circumflex femoral arteries.

A small acetabular branch of the obturator artery also reaches the head, through the ligament of the head of the femur. However, it is a minor source.

The image given below shows the blood supply of the head of the femur:

Related Pearl: Avascular Necrosis (AVN)

It is a rare but severe complication of certain fractures when the blood supply to a segment of bone is affected. 

Common sites of AVN are:

  • Head of femur in fracture neck of femur and posterior dislocation of hip
  • Body of talus in fracture through the neck of talus
  • Proximal pole of scaphoid in fracture through the waist of the scaphoid

Non-traumatic causes of AVN are:

  • Idiopathic
  • Steroids
  • Sickle cell disease
  • Caisson's disease
  • Gaucher's disease
  • Lupus Erythematosus
  • Radiation therapy
  • Alcoholism
  • Hyperlipidemia

Important signs related to avascular necrosis:

  • Crescent sign- Seen in osteonecrosis of the femoral head
  • Hawkin's sign- Seen in the fracture of neck of talus. Presence of this sign indicates that blood supply to the talus is adequate.

questions.text: A neonate presented with features of intestinal obstruction. The X-ray showed the following image. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above plain abdominal radiograph shows a typical double-bubble sign suggestive of duodenal atresia.

The double-bubble represents dilatation of the stomach and the proximal duodenum.

The most common cause of neonatal intestinal obstruction is duodenal atresia. The incidence is 1 in 6000 to 10,000 live births. Duodenal atresia is thought to occur as a result of the failure of vacuolization of the duodenum from its solid cord stage.

It is associated with several conditions, such as:

  • Prematurity
  • Down's syndrome
  • Maternal polyhydramnios
  • Malrotation
  • Annular pancreas
  • Biliary atresia. 

The duodenal obstruction is distal to the ampulla of Vater in most cases therefore the infant infants present with bilious vomiting.

Treatment is by duodenoduodenostomy.

Other options:

Option A: Jejunoileal atresia would present with a triple-bubble sign.

Option B: Esophageal atresia would present with a pouch like finding on the scan.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

questions.text: A 9-month-old boy presents with progressive pallor and abdominal distension. Red cell distribution width is normal. The peripheral smear is shown below. What is the cause of this condition?

choices.text: Substitution of glutamic acid for valine

questions.solution:
The clinical history and peripheral blood smear showing target cells are suggestive of thalassemia. It is caused by decreased β-chain synthesis.

Thalassemia is a hemoglobinopathy that arises due to deficient synthesis of the globin chains. Depending on the chain affected, it is classified into α-thalassemia and β-thalassemia.

β-Thalassemia arises due to the deficient synthesis of β-chains. Normal adult RBCs have HbA, along with HbA2 and fetal haemoglobin (HbF) in small amounts. There is a deficit in the synthesis of HbA with an elevation of HbA2 and HbF levels in β-thalassemia. 

α-Thalassemia is caused by deficient synthesis of α-chains. It can also present as an α-thalassemia trait, with trivial hematologic abnormalities. Excess of β- and γ-globin chains form Bart hemoglobin (γ4) in fetal life and HbH (β4) after birth. Severe deficiency leads to hydrops fetalis.

Ineffective erythropoiesis leads to bone marrow hyperplasia and extramedullary hematopoiesis, which can involve the liver, spleen, and lymph nodes. In β-thalassemia major, anemia manifests 6 to 9 months after birth. HbF levels are markedly elevated. The presence of bony anomalies such as frontal bossing, prominent facial bones, and dental malocclusion is typical.

Other options:

Option A: Sickle cell anaemia is caused by the substitution of glutamic acid by valine.

Option B: G6PD deficiency is characterized by hemolytic anemia triggered by oxidative stress, such as infections or exposure to certain drugs.

Option D: Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria is rare acquired hemolytic anemia characterized by episodes of hemolysis and hemoglobinuria, particularly during sleep. The diagnosis is made by testing for the presence of GPI-anchored proteins using flow cytometry.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of tracheo-esophageal fistula?
questions.solution:
Image C shows the commonest variety of Tracheo-esophageal fistula (TEF).

TEF is an abnormal communication between Esophagus and Trachea. With each breath, the air enters the distal esophagus and the stomach causing gastric distention which presents as abdominal distention. 

Type C is the most common - it has proximal esophageal atresia and distal TEF (the proximal blind pouch ends at the distance of one or two vertebral bodies from the distal TEF).

Tracheoesophageal fistula is associated with VACTERL (vertebral, anorectal, cardiac, tracheal, esophageal, renal, and limb) anomalies. The inability to pass a nasogastric (NG) tube is a crucial pointer in the diagnosis of esophageal atresia. 

 

 

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheo-esophageal Fistula/Esophageal Atresia

Abbreviations:

  • EA: Esophageal atresia
  • TEF: Tracheoesophageal Fistula

questions.text: Which of the following features is false for hypernephroma?

choices.text: Arise from cortex  usually from pre-existing adenoma
May present with rapidly developing  varicocele

questions.solution:
Renal cell carcinoma (hypernephroma) is a radio-resistant tumor.

Adenocarcinoma, the most common neoplasm of the kidney, arises from the renal tubular cells.

Patients having renal cell carcinoma can present with rapidly developing varicocele. Varicocele is usually seen on the left side of the kidney because the left gonadal vein drains into the left renal vein.

 

Related Pearl: Radiosensitive and Radioresistant Tumors

Highly radiosensitive tumors are

  • Lymphoma
  • Seminoma
  • Myeloma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma
  • Wilm’s tumour

 Highly radioresistant tumors are

  • Melanoma
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Pancreatic carcinoma
  • Hepatic carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma

questions.text: What is the oxygen delivery rate of the device shown below?
questions.solution:
The equipment shown in the image is a non-rebreather mask. It can give up to 10-15 litres of oxygen per minute.

The non-rebreather mask is a low-flow device that can be used to deliver oxygen at higher concentrations (FiO2 80-95%). It is used in patients who are severely hypoxic but are ventilating well. It uses a reservoir bag to let the oxygen get concentrated while a one-way valve doesn't allow it to breathe in expired air.

Other examples of low-flow devices are:

  • Nasal cannula
  • Face mask
  • Face tent

High-flow devices include:

  • Venturi mask
  • High-flow nasal cannula
  • Mechanical ventilation

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents with a swelling that has been slowly growing in the past 2 years. On examination, it was variable in consistency and fully mobile. Which of the following statements regarding this tumour is true?

choices.text: The deep lobe is most commonly affected
Most common salivary gland tumor in adults.
Open biopsy is the gold standard investigation of choice
Facial nerve is commonly involved in this condition

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image depicts a case of pleomorphic adenoma. The only true statement regarding pleomorphic adenoma is that it is the most common salivary gland tumor in adults.

Pleomorphic adenoma:

  • Most common benign salivary gland tumor.
  • The most commonly affected gland is the parotid gland. 
  • The superficial lobe is most commonly affected.
  • Also called the mixed tumor, since it has both epithelial and mesenchymal components.

Clinical features:

  • Most commonly affects females around 40 years of age.
  • Most common presenting feature – painless swelling below, in front and behind the ear.
  • The involvement of the deep lobe leads to dumbbell tumour – swelling in both the neck and oral cavity.

Specific features:

  • Slowly growing benign tumour with painless swelling
  • Lobulated, firm, elastic-to-hard consistency and well-defined margins
  • Free from deeper structures with no facial nerve involvement
  • The deep lobe pushes tonsils and faucial pillars

Diagnosis:

  • FNAC – investigation of choice. 
  • Open biopsy contraindicated due to chances of injury to the facial nerve and seedling of the tumour (Option-C)

Treatment: Surgery is the mainstay of treatment - Superficial parotidectomy (Patey's operation). Radiotherapy is considered in high-grade malignancies demonstrating extra-glandular disease, perineural invasion , direct invasion of surrounding tissue, or regional metastases.

Note: Malignant change occurs in about 1.5 to 9.5% of cases of pleomorphic adenoma and is referred to as carcinoma ex pleomorphic adenoma.

Symptoms suggestive of malignant transformation:

  • Rapid growth
  • Pain
  • Paraesthesias
  • Enlarged cervical lymph nodes
  • Restriction of jaw movements
  • Facial weakness
  • Skin invasion
  • Fixation of the mastoid tip.

Pathology:

Gross features:

  • The tumors are rounded, well-demarcated, measuring <6 cm in greatest dimension.
  • They are usually encapsulated, except in some areas such as the palate.
  • The cut surface is gray-white with myxoid and blue translucent areas of the chondroid (cartilage-like) stroma.

 

Microscopic features:

  • The epithelial elements resemble ductal cells or myoepithelial cells. They are arranged as ducts, acini, irregular tubules, strands, or sheets of cells.
  • These epithelial elements are dispersed within a background of loose myxoid and hyaline tissue containing islands of cartilage and, rarely, foci of bone.

The image below shows pleomorphic adenoma of the salivary gland consisting of mixed epithelial (left) and mesenchymal cell components (right).

questions.text: What is the most common cause of the condition given below?
questions.solution:
The CT suggests a diagnosis of subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH) and trauma is the commonest cause.

Subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH) is bleeding into the subarachnoid space, which is the area between the arachnoid membrane and the pia mater surrounding the brain. The diagnosis is suspected when a hyperattenuating material is seen filling the subarachnoid space. Most commonly this is apparent around the circle of Willis, on account of the majority of berry aneurysms occurring in this region, or in the Sylvian fissure.

The most common cause of SAH is head trauma and the second common cause is the rupture of a saccular aneurysm. Young males with a history of spontaneous sudden onset severe headaches with seizures should raise suspicion for subarachnoid haemorrhage (aneurysmal). Symptoms include:

  • Severe headache (thunderclap headache)
  • Rapid onset vomiting
  • Confusion or a lowered level of consciousness
  • Seizures
  • Neck stiffness or neck pain

The tearing of a bridging vein running from the cerebral cortex to the dural sinuses is the most common cause of acute Subdural haemorrhage (SDH).

Fracture to the thin squamous temporal bone with damage to the middle meningeal artery causes Extradural haemorrhage (EDH).

Related Pearl: Intracranial Hemorrhage (ICH)

Extradural hemorrhage (EDH): 

  • Source: Arterial bleed
  • MC- Middle meningeal artery 
  • Cause- Trauma 
  • Clinical features: Lucid interval is characteristic 
  • CT – Lentiform opacity 
  • Treatment: A large or rapidly evolving EDH requires surgical evacuation

 

Subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous bleed 
  • Bridging dural veins 
  • Causes: Trauma, anticoagulants, antiplatelets, alcohol abuse, shaken baby syndrome 
  • Clinical features
    • Acute SDH: may be associated with lucid interval
    • Chronic SDH: drowsiness, headache
  • CT- crescentic opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH)

  • Source: Arterial bleed 
  • Causes:
    • MC – Trauma
    • 2nd MC – Rupture of berry aneurysm
  • MC sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery 
  • Clinical features: Thunderclap headache with neck stiffness +/- FND 
  • Investigations:
    • Non-contrast CT brain,
    • CSF xanthochromia (peaks in 2 days and subsides in 2 weeks) 
  • Treatment:
    • Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm,
    • Triple H therapy – hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution to prevent vasospasm 

 

Intraparenchymal hemorrhage- (MC type of ICH)

  • Source- Arterial bleed 
  • Causes:
    • MC – hypertension
    • Trauma, cerebral amyloid angiopathy, bleeding disorders, neoplasms, vascular malformations 
  • MC sites:
    • Putamen (basal ganglia)
    • Thalamus
    • Cerebellum
    • Pons 
  • Treatment:
    • Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP or fresh platelets as required
    • Surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoms >3 cm in size

questions.text: Which of the following drugs do not reduce mortality in a patient with heart failure?
questions.solution:
The drug that does not reduce mortality in a patient with heart failure is furosemide.

The drugs which reduce mortality in patients with heart failure are :

  • ACE inhibitors
  • Angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs)
  • Angiotensin receptor neprilysin inhibitor (ARNI)
  • Beta-blockers
  • Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists
    • Spironolactone
    • Eplerenone
  • Hydralazine + isosorbide dinitrate.

questions.text: What is the management of asymptomatic and uncomplicated varicose veins?
questions.solution:
The management of asymptomatic and uncomplicated varicose veins is compression stockings.

A patient with an asymptomatic disease and no venous complications like pigmentation, eczema, or venous ulcers can be initially managed with compression stockings. 

Compression stockings provide external pressure to the limb which compresses the veins and improves venous return. There are two lengths available - knee or thigh length. However, knee-length stockings are commonly prescribed as they have better compliance. 

They are useful for the initial management of varicose veins as they relieve symptoms and are a conservative approach. If the varicose veins become symptomatic or become visually distressing then non-conservative approaches described below can be considered. 

Other options: 

Option A - Radiofrequency ablation uses electromagnetic currents to destroy the vein without damaging the other structures. It can only treat junctional and truncal incompetence and not varicosities. 

Option B - Saphenopopliteal ligation is a surgical procedure where the saphenopopliteal junction is dissected with flush ligation. Alternatively, the small saphenous vein can also be ligated as proximally as possible. Sural nerve neuropraxia and common peroneal nerve injury are possible complications. 

Option C - Saphenofemoral ligation is a surgical procedure made where the great saphenous vein is ligated and stripped. There are complications associated with this procedure such as saphenous nerve injury and neovascularization due to trauma leading to reoccurrence.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about breast milk jaundice?

choices.text: It occurs due to the presence of glucuronidase
Phototherapy is not required in all cases
It occurs due to decreased milk intake

questions.solution:
Breast milk jaundice is not due to decreased milk intake. It is due to the presence of glucuronidase in breast milk.

Breast Milk jaundice is seen in about 2–4 % of exclusively breastfed babies. There is significant unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia after the 7th day and may last for 2–3 weeks. This may be caused by the breast milk that might contain β-glucuronidase, which deconjugates intestinal bilirubin and promotes its absorption and other inhibitors of glucuronyl transferase. Persistently high bilirubin levels may require changing from breast milk to infant formula for 24–48 h and/or treatment with phototherapy, without cessation of breastfeeding.

Breastfeeding jaundice (BFJ)

  • Early-onset, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia of breastfed infants.
  • Occurs in the 1st week after birth (usually appears after 24 - 72 hours of birth) 
  • Due to decreased milk intake with dehydration and/or reduced caloric intake. (Breastfeeding failure jaundice)
  • Treatment: Continue breastfeeding and supplementation with formula feeds if needed.

Breast milk jaundice (BMJ)

  • Late-onset, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia of breastfed infants.
  • Occurs after the 7th day with maximal concentrations as high as 10–30 mg/dl reached during the 2nd-3rd week
  • Due to the presence of glucuronidase in breast milk (etiology not entirely clear).
  • Treatment: Continue breastfeeding and the bilirubin gradually decreases but may persist for 3-10 weeks at lower levels; phototherapy may be of benefit in some cases.

Related Pearl: Hyperbilirubinemia- Causes

 Predominantly Unconjugated Hyperbilirubinemia  Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia

Excess production of bilirubin

  

Hemolytic anemias

Biliary tract obstruction

Resorption of blood from internal hemorrhage (e.g., alimentary tract bleeding, hematomas)

 Biliary tract diseases like primary biliary cirrhosis and primary sclerosing cholangitis

Ineffective erythropoiesis (e.g., pernicious anemia, thalassemia)

Dubin Johnson syndrome

Reduced hepatic uptake

Rotor syndrome

Drug interference with membrane carrier systems

  

Some cases of Gilbert syndrome

  

Impaired bilirubin conjugation

  

Physiologic jaundice of the newborn (decreased UGT1A1 activity, decreased excretion)

  

Breast milk jaundice (β-glucuronidases in milk)

  

Genetic deficiency of UGT1A1 activity (Crigler-Najjar syndrome types I and II)

  

Gilbert syndrome

  

Diffuse hepatocellular disease (e.g., viral or drug-induced hepatitis, cirrhosis)

questions.text: X-ray of a patient who had a history of RTA appears as below. What is the likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Right pneumothorax with right lung collapse and right tracheal shift
Right pneumothorax with right lung collapse and left tracheal shift
Right pneumothorax with left lung collapse and left tracheal shift
Right pneumothorax with left lung collapse  and right tracheal shift

questions.solution:
The image shows a right pneumothorax with collapsed right lung and tracheal deviation to the left.

Pneumothorax refers to the presence of gas (air) in the pleural space. When there is a progressive accumulation of intrapleural gas in the thoracic cavity (caused by a valve effect during inspiration and expiration) it is called a tension pneumothorax. It can result in the compression of mediastinal structures and compromise cardiopulmonary function. It is life-threatening and requires emergency intervention.

It is characterized by:

  • Chest pain.
  • Tachypnoea, and acute dyspnea.
  • Sudden onset hemodynamic compromise (tachycardia, hypotension, low O2 saturation, loss of consciousness).
  • Neck vein distention.
  • Tracheal deviation away from the side of the injury.
  • Decreased chest movements on the affected side.
  • Hyper-resonance on percussion on the affected side.
  • Absence or decreased breath sounds on the affected side.

Chest radiograph in spontaneous pneumothorax demonstrates:  

  • Thin, sharp white line, demarcating the visceral pleural edge.
  • Absence of lung markings seen peripheral to this line.
  • Peripheral space radiolucent compared to the adjacent lung. 
  • Lung collapse on the same side of the injury. Subcutaneous emphysema and pneumomediastinum may be seen.
  • Deep sulcus sign (on supine chest radiograph).

Deep sulcus sign: On a supine film (common in the ICU), air collects anteriorly and basally, within the nondependent portions of the pleural space, as opposed to the apex when the patient is upright. 

The costophrenic angle is abnormally deepened when the pleural air collects laterally, producing the deep sulcus sign. It may be the only indication of a pneumothorax in such patients.

questions.text: The diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide is decreased in patients with:
questions.solution:
Diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide (DLCO) is decreased in patients with emphysema.

DLCO measures the ability of the lungs to transfer gas from inhaled air in the alveoli to the red blood cells in pulmonary capillaries.

In general, the DLCO is used to identify the cause of dyspnea or hypoxemia. It is also used to monitor disease progression in interstitial lung disease, and identify pulmonary hypertension in patients at risk, such as those with systemic sclerosis.

DLCO is decreased in patients with:

  • Interstitial lung disease
  • Emphysema (COPD usually have normal DLCO)
  • Bronchiolitis obliterans
  • Pulmonary hypertension
  • Thromboembolic disease
  • Chronic congestive Heart Failure

DLCO is increased in patients with:

  • Alveolar hemorrhage
  • Acute Congestive heart failure
  • Asthma

questions.text: Which among the following best describes sepsis?

choices.text: Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score  ≥ 1
Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score ≥ 2
Suspected or documented infection with qSOFA score  ≥ 1
Suspected or documented infection with SIRS score ≥ 2

questions.solution:
Among the given options suspected or documented infection with SOFA score ≥ 2 best describes sepsis.

Thereby, the best description of sepsis would be :

  • Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score ≥ 2
    OR
  • Suspected or documented infection with qSOFA score ≥ 2

Sepsis is defined as a “life-threatening organ dysfunction due to a dysregulated host response to infection.” It lies in the continuous spectrum between infection and septic shock.

There is no gold-standard method or investigation to diagnose sepsis with certainty. However, the risk of organ dysfunction (sepsis) in patients with suspected infection can be determined using the sequential (sepsis-related) organ failure assessment - SOFA score. This includes:

  • Circulation - Systolic BP & need for vasopressors and platelet count
  • Respiration - PaO2/FiO2 & need for mechanical ventilation
  • Mentation - Glasgow coma score
  • Hepatic function - Bilirubin
  • Renal function - Creatinine

Organ dysfunction is identified by a SOFA score of ≥ 2

A simplified version of the SOFA score is known as the quick sepsis-related organ dysfunction assessment - qSOFA score. It includes:

  • Systolic BP ≤100 mmHg
  • Respiratory rate ≥ 22/min
  • Altered mentation/sensorium

Each criterion carries 1 point. A qSOFA score of ≥ 2 is associated with increased mortality due to sepsis.

SOFA vs qSOFA:

  • SOFA is a more comprehensive and accurate scoring system superior to qSOFA in the ICU setting.
  • qSOFA is a simplified derivative of SOFA for bedside assessment that is particularly useful outside the ICU setting (i.e. ward/emergency department).

 

The Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome (SIRS) score is no longer recommended as it is not specific to infection.

questions.text: A 28-year female presents to your OPD with complaints of vaginal discharge. She is sexually active with her partner. Given below is the image of a smear prepared from the vaginal discharge of a patient. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of clue cells on microscopy is suggestive of bacterial vaginosis.

It is caused due to the alteration in the normal vaginal flora. There is a decrease in the number of lactobacilli. These lactobacilli reduce the pH and release hydrogen peroxide which is antibacterial. Therefore, a decrease in the number of lactobacilli leads to an increase in the number of other organisms like Hemophilus vaginalis, Gardnerella, Mobiluncus, and Mycoplasma hominis. 

According to Amsel's criteria, the discharge has the following characteristics. 

  • White milky non-viscous discharge, adherent to the vaginal wall
  • The pH of the discharge is more than 4.5
  • Fishy odor when mixed with 10% KOH. This is called the Whiff test.
  • Presence of clue cells-the epithelial cells have a fuzzy border due to the adherence of bacteria.
  • Decrease in the number of lactobacilli and increase in the number of Gardnerella and other bacteria.

It is treated with 500 mg of metronidazole twice daily for 7 days.

Shown below is the Gram-stained smear of vaginal discharge of a patient diagnosed with bacterial vaginosis. It reveals vaginal epithelial cells that have a fuzzy border due to the adherence of bacteria. These are called clue cells.

Gram‐negative intracellular diplococci as shown below indicates infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae

 

Below is an image of trophozoite form of Trichomonas vaginalis

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

questions.text: Identify the site of Osiander's sign in the following image
questions.solution:
Osiander's sign refers to increased pulsation felt through lateral fornix by 8 weeks which is demonstrated at B in the given image.

Related Pearl: Uterine Signs in Pregnancy

questions.text: A 3-year-old child develops these lesions over face. The probable diagnosis is _____
questions.solution:
The given image shows skin lesions characterized by shiny, pearly white, umbilicated papules. This description points to Molluscum contagiosum.

  • The age of peak incidence is reported as between 2 and 5 years.
  • The incubation period is variously estimated at 14 days to 6 months.
  • In children, it is mainly caused by Type I molluscum contagiosum virus (MCV-1).
  • PseudoKoebner phenomenon is seen - new lesions develop along line of trauma.
  • There is a relatively higher incidence of MCV‐2 type in adults and HIV infection.
  • Sexually transmitted Molluscum contagiosum may be present over the genital area.
  • Treatment is usually not necessary, although stimulation of the immune response can be done after destructive or inflammatory therapies with salicylic acid, trichloroacetic acid or curettage and expression

Image: Keratinocytes of stratum malpighii become enlarged and acquire eosinophilic inclusion bodies - Henderson-Patterson bodies or molluscum bodies that contain virus particles.

questions.text: An infant born at what period of gestation is considered a late preterm birth?
questions.solution:
Late preterm births include births between 34 to 36 weeks of gestational age.

Timing of delivery Terminology
<33 weeks Early preterm
34 to 36 weeks Late preterm
37 to 38 weeks Early term
39 to 40 weeks Full term

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman is diagnosed with pelvic inflammatory disease. Which of the following is not included in this condition?
questions.solution:
Cervicitis is not included in pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).

Pelvic inflammatory disease is a spectrum of infection and inflammation of the upper genital tract, typically causing:

  • Endometritis
  • Salpingitis
  • Oophoritis
  • Peritonitis

Cervicitis and vaginitis are lower genital tract infections. Cervicitis itself does not have serious long-term complications if treated early and not allowed to progress to PID. It can spread upwards resulting in pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) which can cause fertility problems if left untreated.

The minimum criteria for diagnosis of PID are:

Pain in the lower abdomen + any one of the following:

  • Uterine tenderness
  • Cervical motion tenderness
  • Adnexal tenderness

questions.text: Which of the following anesthetics is to be avoided in a hypertensive patient?
questions.solution:
Ketamine is avoided in hypertensive patients as it has intrinsic sympathomimetic properties and hence can aggravate hypertension.

This is due to central stimulation of the sympathetic nervous system and inhibition of the reuptake of norepinephrine. And hence it should be cautiously used in patients with uncontrolled hypertension, coronary artery disease, congestive heart failure and arterial aneurysms.

Other intravenous induction agents like propofol and thiopentone produce a fall in blood pressure. Etomidate is an induction agent that does not alter the blood pressure.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient was intubated for surgery by a final-year resident. Which of the following is the best method to confirm the position of the endotracheal tube?
questions.solution:
The best method to confirm the position of the endotracheal tube is the end-tidal CO2 concentration assessed by capnography. 

Capnography is a non-invasive method of measurement and graphical display of partial pressure of carbon dioxide (CO2) in exhaled breath or the end-tidal CO2. Capnograph is the device used for measurement and capnogram is the CO2 waveform that is displayed. It is the most reliable indicator of endotracheal tube placement.

The proper placement of the endotracheal tube is indicated by a normal CO2 waveform for at least three breaths.

Other signs to confirm proper endotracheal intubation are symmetrical chest rise, presence of equal bilateral breath sounds, absent breath sounds over the epigastrium, visible condensation in the ETT, large exhaled tidal volume and appropriate compliance of the reservoir bag during manual ventilation.

Absent CO2 waveform tracing despite correct ETT intubation is seen in the following conditions:

  • Severe bronchospasm,
  • Equipment malfunction,
  • Cardiac arrest, or hemodynamic collapse 

Clinical relevance:

  • Capnography does not differentiate endotracheal from endobronchial intubation. Signs of endobronchial intubation include increased peak expiratory pressure, hypoxemia, increased airway pressures, asymmetric chest expansion and the absence of breath sounds over one lung, generally the left.  
  • In esophageal intubation, the capnograph can initially detect some CO2 in the stomach from swallowing expired air. But after a few breaths, this CO2  will be washed out and ETCO2 will become zero. 
  • The most sensitive and earliest indicator of malignant hyperthermia is a persistent increase in ETCO2.

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

questions.text: An oncologist orders a bone scan to assess for bony metastases in a 49-year-old woman with breast cancer.  Which of the following radioactive isotope is used?
questions.solution:
Technetium tagged to various substrates is used for bone scans.

The patient is injected with a small amount of radioactive material such as 600 MBq of technetium-99m-MDP and scanned with a gamma camera, a device sensitive to the radiation emitted by the injected material. MDP (methyl diphosphonate) adsorbs into the hydroxyapatite crystals and accumulates in the areas of active bone formation. 

Given below is a bone scan demonstrating bony metastasis in the pelvis.

questions.text: Lathyrism is caused by which of the following toxic compounds?
questions.solution:
BOAA (Beta oxalyl amino alanine) is the toxic compound causing Lathyrism.

It is due to the consumption of Khesari dal/Lathyrus sativus. Lathyrism is a paralyzing disease of humans and animals.

In humans, it is referred to as neurolathyrism because it affects the nervous system. It is characterized by gradually developing spastic paralysis of lower limbs.

The water soluble property of the toxin is used in removing from the pulses by soaking it in hot water and rejecting the soaked water. Vitamin C in doses of 500-1000mg can be used for the prevention and treatment of lathyrism.

Disease   Food Substance/Contaminant  Toxic Principle

Epidemic dropsy  Argemone oil  Sanguinarine 
Ergotism Bajra, wheat/ Claviceps purpurea Clavine alkaloids
Endemic ascites  Crotalaria/Jhunjhunia  Pyrrolizidine alkaloids

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in tumor lysis syndrome?
questions.solution:
Hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia, is seen in tumour lysis syndrome (TLS). 

It is caused by the destruction of a large number of rapidly proliferating neoplastic cells. It most commonly occurs after the initiation of chemotherapy. It is characterized by:

  • Hyperuricemia
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hyperphosphatemia
  • Hypocalcemia 
  • Acidosis
  • Acute renal failure

The management of TLS includes:

  • Aggressive hydration
  • Allopurinol 
  • Urinary alkalinization with sodium bicarbonate(Only advisable if rasburicase is not readily available. The level of calcium should be serially monitored)
  • Rasburicase - recombinant urate oxidase.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases shows the iceberg phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Tuberculosis shows the iceberg phenomenon.

The iceberg phenomenon of diseases is not shown by diseases such as tetanus, rabies, and measles.

The iceberg phenomenon refers to the concept that only a fraction of cases of a disease are visible or reported, with a larger "hidden" burden below the surface. Once a patient is diagnosed and treated, the impact of underdiagnosis or hidden cases on individual treatment outcomes is minimal. Treatment effectiveness depends more on factors such as drug efficacy, patient adherence, and healthcare delivery rather than the overall prevalence of the disease in the population.

Iceberg phenomenon is shown by:

  • Polio
  • Influenza
  • Rubella
  • Mumps
  • Japanese Encephalitis
  • Diphtheria
  • Hepatitis A and B

Note: Rubella shows a large number of subclinical infections. Thus, it is considered to show the iceberg phenomenon.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with chronic bacterial prostatitis was treated with Cotrimoxazole.  He developed malaise, jaundice, abdominal pain and dark urine. The blood picture is given below. The most likely diagnosis is  ________.
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in the above case scenario is Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency.

The clinical features are suggestive of an acute hemolytic reaction following the administration of cotrimoxazole. A hemolytic attack starts with abrupt onset of malaise, weakness, and abdominal or lumbar pain. After an interval of several hours to 2–3 days, the patient develops jaundice and often dark urine, due to hemoglobinuria. 

The peripheral smear shows characteristic "bite cells" or degmacytes or blister cells. In G6PD deficiency uncontrolled oxidative stress causes hemoglobin to denature and form Heinz bodies. Bite cells result from the removal of Heinz bodies by macrophages in the spleen.

Cotrimoxazole contains sulfamethoxazole which triggers a hemolytic reaction in persons with G6PD deficiency.

Drugs that carry the risk of clinical hemolysis in persons with G6PD Deficiency:

Chloroquine

sulphones

antibiotics

questions.text:
Which of the following are methods of indirect transmission of communicable diseases?
  1. Contact with soil
  2. Droplet nuclei
  3. Fomite borne
  4. Unclean hands and fingers
  5. Transplacental
questions.solution:
Among the given options, droplet nuclei, fomite borne and transmission through unclean hands and fingers are modes of indirect transmission of diseases.

Communicable diseases are classified based on the mode of transmission:

  • Direct:
    • Direct contact (Eg: sexual intercourse)
    • Contact with soil
    • Droplet infection
    • Skin or mucosal inoculation
    • Transplacental 
  • Indirect: 
    • Vehicle-borne
    • Vector-borne
    • Air-borne
      • Droplet nuclei
      • Dust
    • Fomite-borne
    • Unclean hands and fingers

The traditional 5 F's - flies, fingers, fomites, food, and fluids can be used to remember the modes of indirect transmission. Some infectious agents are able to survive in the external environment while maintaining their basic properties of virulence. This is a  requirement for this indirect transmission. 

An important distinction has to be drawn between droplet nuclei infection and droplet infection. The main difference between airborne droplet nuclei and droplet transmission is in the size of infected/contagious particles and whether proximity is required for transmission.

Droplet nuclei/residue from evaporated droplets containing infective microorganisms can result in airborne transmission. The size of these droplet nuclei is <5 μm in diameter, and they can remain suspended in the air for significant periods of time, allowing them to be transmitted over distances >1 m.  There's no need for close proximity or contact. Diseases like chickenpox, measles, tuberculosis, and influenza can spread through airborne transmission.

Droplet transmission occurs when one coughs or sneezes, and contagious droplets from the infected person travel shortly in the air and directly comes in contact with another person's conjunctiva, mouth, or nasal mucosa. The particle size here is >5 μm in diameter. Transmission here requires close proximity and direct contact. Examples of diseases spread via this route include the common cold, diphtheria, and whooping cough.

Direct

Indirect

Direct contact

Droplet infection

Contact with soil

Inoculation into skin or mucosa

Vertical (transplacental)

Vehicle-borne

Vector borne – mechanical or biological

Air borne – droplet nuclei or dust

Fomite borne

Unclean hands and finger

questions.text: Which of the following is not a radiological finding associated with acute pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
Cullen's sign is not a radiological finding associated with this acute pancreatitis. It is a clinical sign seen on abdominal examination.

Cullen’s sign refers to bleeding into the fascial planes causing bluish discolouration around the umbilicus as shown below.

Grey Turner sign refers to bleeding into the fascial planes leading to bluish discolouration of the flanks as shown below.

 

Radiological findings in acute pancreatitis:

Sentinel loop sign - A sentinel loop observed on plain X-ray is a sign of localized paralytic ileus that is primarily associated with acute pancreatitis

Colon cut-off sign - It occurs as a result of a colonic spasm at the splenic flexure. This would result in gaseous distension of the proximal colon with the abrupt termination of the gas at the level of splenic flexure and decompression of the more distal part of the colon.

Renal halo sign - It is produced by the apparent enhancement of the perirenal fat by an adjacent retroperitoneal exudate in the pararenal space.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was admitted to the hospital with difficulty in breathing. He had puffiness around the eyes, pitting edema of the lower limbs, and ascites. His 24-hour urine protein shows a protein level of 4 g/24h. CT chest shows a saddle embolus. What is the cause of this patient's CT findings?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of a diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome complicated to pulmonary embolism. Thrombo-embolic complications in nephrotic syndrome are due to the loss of endogenous anticoagulants such as antithrombin III in the urine.

Nephrotic syndrome is a condition that occurs due to damage in the glomerular capillary walls thereby leading to increased capillary permeability to plasma proteins.

The manifestations and the mechanisms of nephrotic syndrome are:

  • Massive proteinuria (>3.5 grams) as a result of leakage in the barrier formed by glomerular basement membrane, endothelium, and visceral epithelial cells.
  • Hypoalbuminemia (albumin <3g/dL) occurs as a consequence of proteinuria. Also, increased catabolism of the kidney contributes to hypoalbuminemia. 
  • Generalized edema is seen. The edema is soft and pitting seen in periorbital and dependent portions of the body. It occurs as a result of decreased intravascular colloid osmotic pressure and other factors like sodium and water retention lead to edema. 
  • Hyperlipidemia occurs following the increased synthesis of lipoproteins, lipid particles, and decreased catabolism of lipids.
  • Lipiduria is due to leakage of lipids through the glomerular capillary wall.

Increased susceptibility to infections is another complication. It is due to loss of immunoglobulins in the urine.

The image shows the pathophysiology of nephrotic syndrome.

questions.text: An 18-year-old female presented with primary amenorrhea. On examination, she is found to have normally developed breasts and normal external genitalia. She has swelling in the right inguinal region. Ultrasound of the abdomen and pelvis did not reveal the uterus or cervix. The karyotype is XY. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical findings in the question are seen in complete androgen insensitivity syndrome/ testicular feminizing syndrome. In this syndrome, the response of the androgen receptors to androgens is defective.

The findings of the given case can be explained as follows:

  • Primary amenorrhea → Due to the absence of a uterus and cervix.
  • Normally developed breasts → Due to the conversion of the excessive androgens into estrogen.
  • Swelling in the inguinal region → Suggestive of an underdeveloped ectopic testis, caused by loss of action of testosterone on its receptor.
  • Female type external genitalia → In the absence of testosterone's action on genitalia, the genital tubercle enlarges to form the clitoris.
  • Absence of uterus and cervix → Due to the production of Mullerian inhibiting substance from the Sertoli cells of the testis.
  • And finally, the XY karyotype indicates that the patient is a genotypic male.

Other options:

Option A: Swyer's syndrome or pure gonadal dysgenesis occurs as a result of a mutation in the SRY gene or another gene with a testis-determining effect such as DAX1, SF-1, or CBX2. This leads to underdeveloped, dysgenetic gonads that fail to produce androgens or anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH).

Option C:  21-hydroxylase deficiency causes Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia with virilization in females and ambiguous genitalia. It leads to low cortisol and aldosterone levels, resulting in hypotension and hyperkalemia.

Option D: Noonan syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition found in both males and females. It is associated with low IQ, delayed puberty, low fertility, pulmonary stenosis and HOCM.

questions.text: A woman has been working for a company that manufactures roofing sheets for 12 years, but the company does not provide her with personal protective equipment. Which is the most common malignancy seen in such individuals?
questions.solution:
Workers in the roofing industry are exposed to asbestos. Adenocarcinoma of lung is the most common cancer associated with asbestos exposure.

Smoking along with asbestos exposure multiplies the risk to a great extent. Cough and hemoptysis are common presentations.

Pleural mesothelioma is the most specific cancer associated with asbestos exposure, but not the most common. Smoking does not seem to be associated with mesothelioma. Pleuritic chest pain or a mass on the radiographic image are common presentations.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient  with breathing difficulty had high respiratory rate and 88 % saturation on pulse oximetry . Her examination findings with  imaging of spine is as below. Which of the following is seen in this type of  respiratory failure?
questions.solution:
The given patient with scoliosis and acute onset breathing difficulty points towards respiratory failure. It is most likely Type 2 respiratory failure.

It is characterized by low pO2 and high pCO2.

Type 2 respiratory failure is characterized by low pO2 and high pCO2.

Acute respiratory failure refers to acute impairment in gas exchange between the lungs and the blood causing hypoxia with or without hypercapnia. The various types are classified based on the abnormalities in respiratory function and are given below:

  • Type 1 is due to an alveolar oxygenation defect or a diffusion defect leading to hypoxia (low pO2) with normal or low pCO2 but not high pCO2. There is an increased alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient (high pAO2-paO2) and often a ventilation-perfusion(V/Q) mismatch; the volume of air flowing in and out of the lung is not matched to the blood flow to the lung.
    • Interstitial lung disease
    • Pulmonary oedema
    • Lung injury and alveolar haemorrhage
    • Pneumonia
    • Acute severe asthma
  • Type 2 results from the inability to eliminate carbon dioxide effectively due to a ventilation defect. This leads to hypoxia (low pO2) with hypercapnia (high pCO2). As diffusion is not defective, the alveolar-arterial gradient is unaffected with both low pAO2 (alveolar) and low paO2 (arterial). Causes:
    • Respiratory centre: brainstem injury, severe hypothyroidism, sleep apnoea, sedative drug overdose.
    • Chest wall and neuromuscular: Kyphoscoliosis, ankylosing spondylitis, myasthenia gravis, motor neuron disease, myopathy, fatigue.
    • Lung: COPD, pleural pathology, foreign body obstruction.
  • Type 3 results from lung atelectasis commonly during the perioperative period.
  • Type 4 is due to the hypoperfusion of respiratory muscles secondary to shock.

Related Pearl: Types of respiratory failure

II

III Peri-operative respiratory failure Results from lung atelectasis. After general anesthesia.

questions.text: A female patient with a negative urine pregnancy test presents with galactorrhea. An MRI was done which revealed a large pituitary tumor. If the patient is not willing for surgery, which of the following is the best drug for treatment?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette points to a diagnosis of prolactinoma and the best drug for the treatment of the condition is bromocriptine.

Prolactinomas are pituitary tumors that can present as microadenomas or macroadenomas. Tumors <1cm in diameter and no regional invasion are known as microadenomas. It is more commonly seen in women. Tumors >1cm in size are known as macroadenomas. It can be locally invasive. Prolactin levels >200μg/L are suggestive of prolactinomas. 

Women present with features such as amenorrhea, infertility, and galactorrhea. Visual field defects can also be seen. Symptoms in males include impotence, infertility, and loss of libido. An MRI is recommended in all patients who present with hyperprolactinemia.

Microadenomas can be managed with regular monitoring of prolactin levels and MRI scans, if fertility is not a requisite. Oral dopamine agonists such as bromocriptine and cabergoline are used for medical management. They are agonists at D2 receptors. Side effects include constipation, nasal stuffiness, and dry mouth. Resistance or intolerance to these drugs requires surgical debulking. Cases that do not respond to medical or surgical management can be treated with radiotherapy.

Other options:

Option B: Promethazine is an antihistamine used to treat motion sickness, pruritus, and oculogyric crisis.

Option C: Octreotide is a somatostatin analog that is used in acromegaly, variceal bleeding, and hepatorenal syndrome.

Option D: Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic used in refractory schizophrenia and mania.
