questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and low-grade fever. Physical examination demonstrates crepitus over the right upper quadrant. Ultrasound evaluation reveals air in the walls of the gall bladder. What is the indicated management in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and USG findings of air in the wall of the gall bladder are suggestive of emphysematous cholecystitis. This is managed with emergency cholecystectomy.

Emphysematous cholecystitis is a life-threatening form of acute cholecystitis that is more common in older patients with diabetes mellitus. The term refers to the presence of gas in the gallbladder lumen or wall. It is due to a secondary infection of the gallbladder wall with gas-forming organisms such as Clostridium welchii. Escherichia coli, staphylococci, streptococci, Pseudomonas, and Klebsiella may also be isolated.

Patients present with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and low-grade fever. Crepitus is present on physical examination. Mild to moderate unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia may be present. USG reveals air in the walls of the gall bladder.

Emphysematous cholecystitis often heralds the development of gangrene, perforation, and other complications. Hence emergency cholecystectomy is indicated for the management of these patients.

questions.text: A woman comes to your clinic for a follow-up. An obstetric scan was ordered which showed a 12-week intra-uterine pregnancy with a complete placenta previa. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: Painful recurrent vaginal bleeding can occur
The size of the uterus corresponds to gestational age
Fetal condition is generally good until bleeding is severe
Vaginal delivery cannot be tried in this lady

questions.solution:
Painless recurrent vaginal bleeding is seen in placenta previa.

Clinical features of placenta previa:

  • Bleeding per vaginum - sudden onset, painless, recurrent, bright red in colour, sometimes a history of warning haemorrhage is present
  • Uterus - relaxed, soft, no tenderness, size proportional to the period of gestation
  • Floating head i.e., persistent displacement of fetal head as it cannot be pushed down into the pelvis
  • Fetal heart sound - present. Fetal condition is generally good until bleeding is severe
  • Stallworthy sign - seen in the low-lying placenta, especially the posterior type. Slowing of fetal heart rate (FHR) on pressing the head down into the pelvis, which recovers promptly as pressure is relieved, is called the Stallworthy sign.

Central placenta previa is a contraindication for vaginal delivery. Cesarean delivery is recommended for all patients with placenta previa where it is located within 2 cm of the internal os. Vaginal delivery may be considered when the placental edge is located 2-3 cm away from the internal os.

questions.text: A concerned mother brings her 15-day old baby to you with complaints of decreased activity and vomiting. On examination, the baby is hypotensive, has depressed fontanelles and reduced skin turgor. The image of the external genitalia of the baby is shown below. Which metabolic abnormality can you expect to see in this baby?
questions.solution:
The image shows ambiguous genitalia. This along with signs of dehydration and hypotension suggest congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency. Hyperkalemia and hyponatremia (due to mineralocorticoid deficiency) can be seen in this condition. 

21-hydroxylase enzyme hydroxylates progesterone and 17-hydroxyprogesterone to yield 11-deoxycorticosterone and 11-deoxycortisol, respectively. They help in the synthesis of aldosterone and cortisol. Therefore, the deficiency of this enzyme leads to the deficiencies of aldosterone and cortisol.

Also, the accumulated steroid precursors are diverted into the pathway for androgen (testosterone) production.

Clinical profile in 21-hydroxylase deficiency:

  • Aldosterone deficiency: Salt-wasting crises (hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, hypotension, and metabolic acidosis)
  • Cortisol deficiency: Hypoglycemia, hyperpigmentation (due to increased ACTH production), weight loss, weakness, anorexia, vomiting, and shock
  • Androgens excess: Virilization of females and precocious puberty in males

Without treatment, shock, cardiac arrhythmias, and death may occur within days or weeks.

Related Pearl: Variants of Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH)

21-Hydroxylase deficiency

 17-Hydroxylase deficiency 11β-Hydroxylase disease 3β-HSD

Deficiency of cortisol and aldosterone;

↑ in testosterone

 Deficiency of cortisol and sex hormones; ↑ in aldosterone Deficiency of cortisol; ↑ in deoxycorticosterone (mineralocorticoid) and testosterone Deficiency of cortisol, aldosterone and testosterone; ↑ in DHEA
Salt wasting crises Salt retention and  hypertension

Salt retention and  hypertension

Virilization of females (ambiguous genitalia 46XX)     Failure of sexual development in females at puberty Virilization of females  (ambiguous genitalia 46XX) Females are mildly
virilized (DHEA is a weak androgen)

Note: In 11β-Hydroxylase deficiency, Aldosterone synthetic capacity is normal and some corticosterone is synthesized from progesterone by intact aldosterone synthase enzyme. Thus, it is unusual for patients to manifest signs of adrenal insufficiency.

questions.text: A patient with carcinoma endometrium is treated with pelvic external beam irradiation. Which of the following organs is likely to be affected the most?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the ovary is most likely to be affected as it is the most radiosensitive organ. 

Radiosensitivity of pelvic organs is as follows: ovary>rectum>bladder>vagina. Radiation tolerance dose for ovary is 2-3 Gy whereas vagina 90 Gy. Hence, among the given options, the vagina is the most radioresistant organ.

The radiation dose necessary to induce ovarian failure is age-dependent. A single dose of 3-4 Gray can induce amenorrhea in almost all women >40 yrs of age. In young women, oogenesis is much less sensitive to radiation as compared to the elderly. 

Radiosensitivity of various tissues is summed up in the table given below: 

  Most radiosensitive Least radiosensitive
Tissue Bone marrow, Gonads Nervous tissue, Muscle fibers
Blood cells Lymphocytes Platelets
Stages of cell cycle G2M interphase S phase
Cell types Rapidly dividing Quiescent
Ocular structure Lens Sclera
Layer of retina Rods Ganglion cell layer

The skin is most commonly affected due to radiation. Stratum basalis is the layer of the skin most affected.

Later - Recycling

 Note: Ash from incineration of biomedical waste shall be disposed of at common hazardous waste treatment and disposal facility. However, it may be disposed of in a municipal landfill, if the toxic metals in incineration ash are within the regulatory quantities as defined under the Hazardous Waste (Management and Handling and Transboundary Movement) Rules, 2008 as amended from time to time.

questions.text: Which of the following skin finding in a pregnant woman needs further evaluation?
questions.solution:
Image 2 showing acanthosis nigricans is not a normal change seen in pregnancy and hence it needs evaluation if seen in pregnancy. The other images show striae gravidarum, chloasma gravidarum and linea alba which are normal changes seen in pregnancy.

Acanthosis nigricans(AN) is characterized by a symmetrical darkening and thickening of the skin with a vel­vety texture. More common in the intertriginous areas, mainly the axillae, groins, submammary folds, and neck. Obesity and insulin resistance is the most common association with AN, and it can regress with weight loss. It is more common in patients with darker skin. 

Other conditions associated with AN:

  • Acromegaly and gigantism
  • Diabetes
  • HAIR-AN syndrome
  • Polycystic ovary syndrome
  • Gastric cancer
  • Gynaecological cancer

Treatment of the underlying condition is the mainstay. AN associated with obesity responds to dietary restriction and weight loss. The cosmetic appear­ance of the condition can be treated with topical retinoids or topical keratolytics

Other options:

Option A: Linea nigra is a brownish-black pigmented area that stretches from the xiphisternum to the symphysis pubis in the midline. The pigmentary changes may be due to melanocyte-stimulating hormone from the anterior pituitary. The pigmentation disappears after delivery. Similar changes are observed in women taking oral contraceptives may be due to estrogen and progesterone may be related to it as.

Option C: Striae gravidarum is slightly depressed linear marks with varying length and breadth found in pregnancy. They are predominantly found in the abdominal wall below the umbilicus. They appear pinkish in colour. They can sometimes be found over the thighs and breasts. These stretch marks represent the scar tissues in the deeper layer of the cutis. 

Option D: Chloasma gravidarum also called pregnancy mask is an extreme form of pigmentation around the cheek, forehead, and around eyes. It may be patchy or diffuse. It disappears spontaneously after delivery.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient presents to the ER following a road traffic accident. His respiratory rate is 28/min and BP is 80/50 mmHg. Cyanosis and inspiratory stridor are present. He has an open fracture of the shaft of the femur. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Obtain IV access to begin fluids
Reduce the shaft of the femur fracture
Endotracheal intubation and cervical spine restriction
Tube thoracostomy in the right hemithorax

questions.solution:
Since the given patient has signs of airway compromise such as cyanosis and tachypnea, the most appropriate next step would be endotracheal intubation and cervical spine restriction.

The primary survey consists of the following ABCDEs:

  • Airway maintenance with restriction of cervical spine motion
  • Breathing and ventilation
  • Circulation and hemorrhage control
  • Disability (assessment of neurologic status)
  • Exposure and environment control

This sequence is based on the degree of threat to life that can be caused by various injuries and must always be adhered to. Therefore, the most life-threatening abnormality has to be addressed first. For example, regardless of the cause of airway compromise, the airway has to be managed on priority because a compromised airway will rapidly kill the patient. 

If the patient is able to communicate verbally, the airway is unlikely to be compromised. Objective signs of airway obstruction include agitation, cyanosis, stridor, displaced trachea, and use of accessory muscles for respiration. If there is any doubt regarding the patient's ability to maintain a patent airway, a definitive airway should be established. This can be in the form of endotracheal intubation, orotracheal airway, or surgical airway (cricothyroidotomy or tracheostomy). ]

After the airway is secured, IV access is obtained to begin fluids. After the patient has been stabilised, the fracture can be addressed.

questions.text: A one-and-a-half-year-old child is brought to the hospital with a history of breathlessness, fever, cough, and persistent vomiting. On examination, the respiratory rate was 46/min and stridor was present . Which is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Administer IV antibiotics and refer to higher centre
Administer oral antibiotics, warn of danger signs, and send home

questions.solution:
From the given clinical picture, it can be inferred that the child has severe pneumonia. The treatment for severe pneumonia is to administer IV antibiotics and refer to a higher centre.

Pneumonia diagnosis is as given in the table below:

Age of child Fast breathing RR
<2 months 60 breaths/min
2-12 months 50 breaths/min
1-5 years 40 breaths/min

 

 According to the latest SAANS guidelines (Social Awareness and Actions to Neutralize Pneumonia Successfully), a child with Severe Pneumonia needs to provide oral antibiotics and refer the patient to a higher centre.

For classifying Pneumonia, SAANS guidelines of India are similar to the IMNCI protocols of WHO, except it allows ASHA to take the decision for advising Home based treatment as she has been trained for classifying Pneumonia. Also in the SAANS guidelines, chest indrawing is a feature of severe pneumonia, while it comes under pneumonia in the IMNCI guidelines.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl was brought to her pediatrician with complaints of repeated hand wringing movements and finger-licking.  On examination, microcephaly and marked regression of language milestones were noticed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This girl with stereotyped hand-wringing movements, repetitive behaviour, regressed language milestones, and microcephaly most likely has Rett syndrome.

It is an X-linked dominant disease caused by a mutation of MECP2 gene and hence predominantly seen in girls. The onset is after a few months of apparently normal development.

Between the ages of 6 months to 2 years, affected children develop progressive encephalopathy. Patients typically have

  • Regression of previously acquired milestones following a period of normal development. This can include motor and language milestones.
  • Stereotypic hand movements such as hand wringing, biting, or licking the fingers, and poor muscle coordination.
  • Head circumference is normal at birth, but between the age of 6 months to 1 year, growth begins to decelerate leading to microcephaly. Seizures are an associated feature in a large number of cases. 

Supportive treatment is given. Physiotherapy is beneficial for muscular dysfunction. Anticonvulsants may be required to control seizures.

Other options:

Option A: Social anxiety disorder also known as social phobia is a fear of social situations like social gatherings, oral presentations, and meeting new people. They are fearful of embarrassing themselves in such situations.

Option B: Asperger's syndrome is a type of autism spectrum disorder. There is marked nonverbal communicative gestures and failure to develop relationships with peers. No significant delay in language milestones or cognitive development is seen. The intelligence remains normal.

Option D: Heller's syndrome is a type of autism spectrum disorder. It is also known as childhood disintegrative disorder. It is predominantly seen in boys. They have marked regression in intellectual, social, and language functions after 2 years of apparently normal development.

questions.text: An elderly patient is brought to the emergency in a comatose state. Examination reveals serum glucose levels of 500 mg/dL, arterial pH of 7.33, elevated plasma ketones, and normal serum potassium levels. What should be added to the saline in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the patient has diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). The patient needs to be started on IV fluids and insulin at a dose of 0.1 unit per kg. 

Diabetic ketoacidosis is an acute complication of type 1 diabetes mellitus. The symptoms include nausea, vomiting, and severe abdominal pain.

Signs:

  • Kussmaul breathing
  • Fruity odor on the patient’s breath
  • Tachycardia
  • Dehydration
  • Hypotension

Blood parameters:

  • Hyperglycemia – 250 – 600 mg%
  • Pseudohyponatremia- There is 1.6-mmol/L reduction in serum sodium level for each 5.6-mmol/L rise in the serum glucose level.
  • Overall total-body K+ deficit, however, the serum K+ at presentation may be mildly elevated, secondary to the acidosis
  • Osmolality– 300–320 mOsm/kg
  • Plasma ketones– Positive
  • Metabolic acidosis– Increased anion gap
  • Serum bicarbonate <15 meq/L– Best initial investigation
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Hyperamylasemia

Management of DKA

  • Admit to hospital assess for serum electrolytes and acid-base status
  • Replace fluids- 2-3 liters (10-20 mL/kg/hr) of normal saline should be administered over 1-3 hours. Subsequently 0.45% saline at 250-500 mL/hr. It can be changed to 5% glucose and 0.45% saline at 150–250 mL/h when plasma glucose reaches 250 mg/dL.
  • Administer IV short-acting insulin regular insulin. 0.1 units/kg of insulin should be administered immediately as a bolus dose. This is followed by an intravenous infusion of 0.1 units/kg. Serum potassium levels should be checked before initiating insulin. If the levels are high, then it has to be corrected and then insulin should be started.
  • The above measures should be continued until the serum glucose levels reach 150–200 mg/dL, and acidosis is resolved. Insulin infusion may be decreased to 0.02–0.1 units/kg per hour.
  • Long-acting insulin can be started when the patient starts eating.

The chart shows the management algorithm for DKA.

questions.text: A child with a fever and rash was brought to your OPD. Oral findings as shown in the image were observed. During which period is the disease communicable to others?

choices.text: Before as well as after the appearance of rash.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing koplik spots is suggestive of measles. It is communicable before as well as after the appearance of rash.

Measles, otherwise known as rubeola, is caused by the paramyxovirus which is an RNA virus. The virus has an incubation period of 10 to 14 days. It is a droplet infection and the period of communicability ranges from 4 days before to 4 days after the appearance of the rash. 

The prodrome phase begins with mild fever, conjunctivitis, upper respiratory tract infection, and pathognomonic Koplik spots. Koplik spots are small, bluish-white ulcerations on the buccal mucosa at the level of the premolars.

This is followed by the appearance of a characteristic dusky red maculopapular rash that begins at the face and spreads to the torso and extremities. Lymphadenopathy may be present.

The diagnosis of measles infection is mainly clinical but may be confirmed by serological demonstration of serum IgM antibodies. 

The management is mainly supportive in form of relieving common symptoms such as fever, cough, and nasal congestion and providing adequate nutritional support.

Related Pearl: Periods of Isolation for Selected Diseases

Disease

Chickenpox

 

Until all lesions are crusted – 6 days usually.

Measles

 

From onset of catarrhal stage to 7 days of rash.

Cholera, diphtheria

 

3 days after tetracycline start until 48 hours.

Shigellosis and salmonellosis

 

Until 3 consecutive negative stool cultures.

Hepatitis A

 

3 weeks.

Influenza

 

3 days after onset.

Polio

 

2 weeks in adult; 6 weeks in children.

Tuberculosis (sputum +)

 

Until 3 weeks of effective chemotherapy.

Herpes zoster

 

6 days after onset of rash.

Mumps

 

Until swelling subsides.

Pertussis

 

4 weeks or until paroxysms cease.

Meningococcal meningitis

 

Until first 24 hours of effective antibiotic therapy are completed

Streptococcal pharyngitis

 

Until first 6 hours of effective antibiotic therapy are completed

questions.text: You are a resident observing an intern resuscitate a newborn in the labor room. After half a minute of bag and mask ventilation by the intern, the infant is still pale and hypoxic. What would you advise the intern?

choices.text: Readjust the mask and head position

questions.solution:
The next step in this newborn with ineffective bag and mask ventilation (BMV) is to readjust the mask and reposition the head.

Positive pressure ventilation (PPV) by BMV is given when infants fail to breathe at birth. The infant's neck is slightly extended to make sure the airway is open. The care provider is at the head end of the baby and a face mask of appropriate size is chosen to cover the mouth and nose. The adequacy of ventilation is indicated by visible chest rise and when normal chest rise is observed, ventilation should be started.

Increasing heart rate; spontaneous respiration; and improvement in color, saturation, and tone help to assess the infant's improvement.

When there is no improvement after 30 seconds of BMV(according to Nelson's textbook of pediatrics) or 15 seconds of BMV (according to the Indian Association of Pediatrics), ventilation corrective steps should be taken. It is as follows - MRSOPA

  • Mask has to be reapplied 
  • Reposition the infant's head
  • Suction the secretions
  • Open the mouth
  • Increase the Pressure
  • Use an Alternative airway.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a neuroendocrine tumour?
questions.solution:
Prolactinoma is a type of adenoma and is not a neuroendocrine tumour.

Neuroendocrine tumours (NETs) are a type of neoplasm characterised by its capacity to synthesise and secrete monoamines, due to its neuroendocrine origin.

NETs can begin in any part of the body, including

  • Gastrointestinal (GI) tract: NETs develop most commonly in the GI tract, specifically in the large intestine, small intestine, and appendix.
  • Lung NETs occur in the bronchial system(bronchial carcinoid)
  • Pancreas: Insulinoma, glucagonoma, somatostatinoma, carcinoid, gastrinoma, VIPoma.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered the investigation of choice for the evaluation of a patient with suspected peptic ulceration?
questions.solution:
Gastroduodenoscopy is considered the investigation of choice for the evaluation of a patient with suspected peptic ulcer disease.

Gastroduodenoscopy helps to directly visualise the ulcer and simultaneously perform a biopsy to rule out malignancy. This makes it a better investigation compared to others.

Gastric peptic ulcers are predominantly located along the lesser curvature near the interface of the body and antrum. The most common site of peptic ulcer is the anterior wall of the proximal duodenum, within a few centimeters of the pyloric valve. 

The image below shows a peptic ulcer with a round to oval and sharply punched-out defect, and a clean mucosal margin.

Complications of peptic ulcers:

  • Bleeding - It is the most common complication of posterior duodenal ulcer.
  • Perforation - It is the most common complication of anterior duodenal ulcer and gastric ulcer.
  • Obstruction.
  • Hour-glass deformity of the stomach - Large long-standing gastric ulcers can lead to fibrosis. Fibrosis if present can cause hourglass constriction of the stomach. Barium meal shows double pouched stomach.
  • Tea-pot deformity (handbag stomach) - It is caused by cicatrization and shortening of the lesser curvature.
  • An ulcer can erode posteriorly into the pancreas and anteriorly into the liver.
  • Malignancy.
